revision.text:
{{update|date=May 2016}} {{EngvarB|date=April 2014}} [[File:All out of horse burgers - Tesco supermarket - 8 February 2013.jpg|thumb|Sign in a [[Tesco]] supermarket following the removal of beefburgers adulterated with horse meat]]
The '''2013 horse meat scandal''' was a scandal in Europe in which foods advertised as containing beef were found to contain undeclared or improperly declared [[horse meat]] – as much as 100% of the meat content in some cases.<ref name=bbcconf>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21375594 |title= Findus beef lasagne contained up to 100% horsemeat, FSA says |date=7 February 2013 |accessdate=7 February 2013|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> A smaller number of products also contained other undeclared meats, such as pork.<ref name="guardburg"/> The issue came to light on 15 January 2013, when it was reported that horse [[DNA]] had been discovered in frozen [[beefburger]]s sold in several Irish and British supermarkets.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/9857136/Horse-meat-scandal-timeline.html|work=The Daily Telegraph|title=Horse meat scandal: timeline|accessdate=16 July 2017}}</ref>
The analysis stated that {{nowrap|23 out of 27}} samples of beef burgers also contained pig DNA; pork is a taboo food in the [[Muslim]] and [[Jewish]] communities.<ref name="fsai_burger">{{cite web|title=Results of Burgers Analysed|url=http://www.fsai.ie/uploadedFiles/News_Centre/Burger_results_2013_01.pdf|date=22 January 2013|accessdate=16 March 2013|publisher=Food Safety Authority of Ireland}}</ref>
While the presence of undeclared meat was not a health issue, the scandal revealed a major breakdown in the traceability of the food supply chain, and the risk that harmful ingredients could have been included as well. Sports horses, for example, could have entered the food supply chain, and with them the veterinary drug [[phenylbutazone]] which is banned in food animals. The scandal has since spread to 13 other European countries, and European authorities have decided to find an EU-wide solution. They initiated meat testing of about 4,000 horse meat samples for the veterinary drug.
== Investigations ==
=== Irish Investigations === Investigations by the [[Food Safety Authority of Ireland]] (FSAI) resulted in Ireland being the first EU state to report the presence of horse meat in beef and make the results public.<ref>Dunmore, Charlie and Croft, Adrian, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/13/us-eu-horsemeat-idUSBRE91C0LH20130213 Horsemeat scandal set to spur tougher EU food tests], Reuters, 13 February 2013</ref> The first positive test for [[equus (genus)|equine]] [[DNA]] was on 10 December 2012.<ref name="ceo-statement"/> It carried out additional tests on 18 and 21 December.<ref name="ceo-statement">{{cite web|url=http://www.fsai.ie/news_centre/oireachtas_05.02.2013.html|title=CEO Statement to the Joint Oireachtas Committee on Agriculture, Food and the Marine|date=5 February 2013|accessdate=15 February 2013}}</ref> The FSAI then sent samples to the [[Eurofins Scientific|Eurofins]] laboratory in Germany. Professor Alan Reilly of the FSAI testified to the [[Oireachtas]] on 5 February 2013 that the results indicated the presence of equine DNA, but not the amount. The [[IdentiGen]] Laboratory and the [[Eurofins Scientific|Eurofins Laboratory]] were asked to determine the amount of horse meat in the samples.<ref name="ceo-statement"/> On 21 December 2012, the FSAI requested that the [[Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine]] in Ireland obtain further samples.<ref name="ceo-statement"/> These were sent to the Identigen laboratory on 4 January 2013.<ref name="ceo-statement"/>
Results were received back from Eurofins and Identigen on 11 January 2013.<ref name="ceo-statement"/> Professor Reilly reported on 5 February that quantitative results from Identigen were received by the FSAI late on the evening of 11 January 2013. Of the ten burger products that tested positive for equine DNA, all but one was at low levels. The quantification of the equine DNA in this one burger product gave an estimated amount of 29% equine DNA relative to the beef DNA content of the burger product. This product was manufactured by Silvercrest on behalf of Tesco. At this point, there was no explanation for the finding of 29% equine DNA relative to beef DNA in this single sample.<ref name="ceo-statement"/> On 14 January 2013 the FSAI informed the [[Department of Health (Ireland)|Department of Health]] and the Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine of the final results. On the same day it also informed the [[Food Standards Agency]] in the United Kingdom.
The next day, 15 January 2013, the FSAI advised the five retailers concerned, [[Tesco]], [[Dunnes Stores]], [[Aldi]], [[Lidl]] and [[Iceland (supermarket)|Iceland]], of their findings;<ref name="ceo-statement"/> all these firms withdrew the offending products.<ref name="ceo-statement"/> The media and newspapers of 16 January 2013 led with the story, focusing on the one burger which tested positive for 29% equine DNA.<ref>[http://www.rte.ie/news/2013/0115/362894-horse-meat-beef-burgers/ Horse DNA found in beef burgers], Raidió Teilifís Éireann, 24 January 2013. Retrieved 15 February 2013.</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/feb/08/how-horsemeat-scandal-unfolded-timeline|title=How the horsemeat scandal unfolded – timeline|work=The Guardian|date=15 February 2013|agency=Press Association|accessdate=15 February 2013|location=London}}</ref>
Another significant investigation into the horse meat affair in Ireland by Ireland’s Department of Agriculture, published its findings in March 2013. This report’s investigation “concluded that there is no evidence that Silvercrest knowingly purchased horsemeat”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.agriculture.gov.ie/media/migration/publications/2013/EquineDNAreportMarch2013190313.pdf |format=PDF |title=Equine DNA & Mislabelling of Processed Beef Investigation |publisher=Agriculture.gov.ie |accessdate=3 June 2015}} </ref>
=== UK Investigations === In the UK, a House of Commons [[Select Committee on Environment, Food and Rural Affairs]] report on the horse meat incident was not critical of UK or Irish producers. It expressed concern that horsemeat contamination was the result of fraud and other criminal activity across the EU. Chair of the Committee [[Anne McIntosh]] MP said: “The evidence suggests a complex network of companies trading in and mislabeling beef or beef products which is fraudulent and illegal.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/commons-select/environment-food-and-rural-affairs-committee/news/food-contamination-report/|title=The Role of the Food Standards Agency must be clearer|work=UK Parliament}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Alison Healy |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/consumer/goodman-firm-says-horse-meat-crisis-has-changed-it-for-the-better-1.1652982 |title=Goodman firm says horse meat crisis has changed it for the better |work=[[Irish Times]] |date=13 January 2014 |accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref>
The second major UK report on the horse meat incident was conducted by Professor Chris Elliott, the Director of the Institute for Global Food Security at [[Queen's University Belfast]]. In his independent report he argues that food crime was at the heart of the horse meat incident: and made a range of suggestions for how this could be tackled. “Industry, government and enforcement agencies should, as a precautionary principle, always put the needs of consumers above all other considerations, and this means giving food safety and food crime prevention – i.e. the deterrence of dishonest behavior – absolute priority over other objectives.” <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/elliott-review-into-the-integrity-and-assurance-of-food-supply-networks-interim-report|title=Elliott review into the integrity and assurance of food supply networks: interim report|work=www.gov.uk}}</ref>
=== Test results === Of 27 beef burger products tested, 37% were positive for horse DNA, and 85% were positive for pig DNA. Of 31 beef meal products tested, 21 were positive for pig DNA but all were negative for horse DNA. {{nowrap|19 salami}} products were tested but were negative for all foreign DNA.<ref>{{cite web|title=FSAI Survey Finds Horse DNA in Some Beef Burger Products|url=http://www.fsai.ie/news_centre/press_releases/horseDNA15012013.html|publisher=Food Safety Authority of Ireland|accessdate=16 January 2013|date=15 January 2013}}</ref> Of the 37% of beef products tested positive for horse DNA, Tesco's inexpensive Everyday Value Beef Burgers tested at 29.1%. All other reported brands had less than 0.3% horse DNA. These products originated from [[Liffey Meats]] and [[Silvercrest Foods]] in Ireland and [[Dalepak Hambleton]] food processing plant in the United Kingdom. Trace amounts of horse DNA were also found in raw ingredients imported from Spain and the Netherlands.<ref name="fsai">{{cite web|url=http://www.fsai.ie/news_centre/press_releases/horseDNA15012013.html|title=Horse DNA found in some beef burger products |publisher=Fsai.ie |date=15 January 2013 |accessdate=22 January 2013}}</ref>
Laboratory DNA investigations were requested by the authorities into possible [[donkey]] meat [[adulterant|adulteration]] of minced meat products labelled as 100% beef.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lichfield|first=John|title=Horsemeat found in British supermarkets 'may be donkey'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/horsemeat-found-in-british-supermarkets-may-be-donkey-8489030.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=11 February 2013|date=10 February 2013|location=London}}</ref> British company Primerdesign Ltd provided many of the tests to laboratories and companies wishing to test for contamination.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.setsquared.co.uk/news/southampton-company-primerdesign-help-tackle-horse-meat-food-scandal |title=Southampton company PrimerDesign help tackle horse meat food scandal | SETsquared Partnership |publisher=Setsquared.co.uk |date= |accessdate=28 May 2014}}</ref>
== Companies ==
=== ABP Food Group === [[File:ABP Food Group Logog 2013.png|thumb|right|100px|ABP Food Group Logo]]
By 16 January 2013 four subsidiaries of ABP had been accused of supplying adulterated meat. They were Silvercrest in County Monaghan, Dalepak in North Yorkshire, Freshlink in Glasgow, ABP Nenagh in County Tipperary, Ireland and Dairy Crest, Rossington.
Hamburger meat from Silvercrest Foods, a subsidiary of [[Larry Goodman]]'s ABP Food Group, in [[County Monaghan]], Ireland, was found to contain 29% horse meat relative to beef. Porcine DNA was also found.<ref name="guardburg">{{cite news|title=Cameron tells supermarkets: horsemeat burger scandal unacceptable|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jan/16/tesco-burgers-off-shelves-horsemeat|date=16 January 2013|last1=Meikle|first1=James|last2=McDonald|first2=Henry|location=London|work=The Guardian}}</ref> Tesco dropped Silvercrest as a supplier of processed meat, but ABP said that it "welcomed their decision to continue sourcing fresh beef from other ABP companies".<ref>{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Tracy|title=Burger King: There is NO horse meat in our burgers — and we've got the DNA tests to prove it |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/eats/burger-king-dna-shows-horse-burgers-article-1.1253504 |work=Daily News|location=New York|accessdate=13 February 2013|date=1 February 2013}}</ref> On 15 February 2013 Tesco said, "We will no longer work with the suppliers who fell below our very high standards."<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.tescoplc.com/index.asp?pageid=17&newsid=743 |title=Tesco comments on test results |publisher=Tesco PLC |date=15 February 2013 |accessdate=17 February 2013}}</ref>
The first apparent instance of fresh beef being adulterated with horse meat was reported by [[Asda]], which removed its 500-gram own-label beef Bolognese sauce from sale.<ref>{{cite news|title=Horsemeat scandal: 'fresh beef' discovery as tests overwhelm laboratories |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/feb/14/horsemeat-beef-tests |work=The Guardian|accessdate=14 February 2013|date=15 February 2013|last1=Carrington|first1=Damian|last2=Meikle|first2=James|last3=Neville|first3=Simon|location=London}}</ref> The sauce was supplied by [[Greencore]], which said in a statement that the meat in the sauce had been supplied by ABP Food Group's Nenagh plant in County Tipperary, Ireland.<ref>{{cite news|title=Three held in horsemeat mislabelling investigation |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21466074|accessdate=14 February 2013|date=14 February 2013|work=BBC News}}</ref> On 4 March 2013 Greencore announced<ref>{{cite news|title=Greencore update re ASDA product withdrawal and ongoing testing|url=http://www.greencore.com/content.asp?page=581}}</ref> that "multiple further tests for the presence of equine DNA on the same batch of the same product using both screening and quantitative tests (in line with FSA testing protocols) at two different, independent accredited laboratories have all produced negative results" and "an extensive programme of testing of other finished product and raw material at the Bristol facility has produced negative results for the presence of equine DNA. The investigation of the overall incident, overseen by an independent expert... included an audit of ABP Food Group's plant in Nenagh, Ireland... found no evidence of contamination in the supply chain."
[[Burger King]], which has more than 500 fast food outlets in Ireland and the UK, dropped Silvercrest as a supplier,<ref name="irishtimes_cancel">{{cite news|title=Burger King drops Silvercrest as supplier|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2013/0124/1224329226269.html|date=24 January 2013|last = Gleeson|first=Colin|work=The Irish Times}}</ref> using suppliers in Germany and Italy instead,<ref name="chaty_src">{{cite web|title=Neigh!!!!: Burger King finally admits it has been selling beef burgers containing horsemeat : ChatyChaty.com|url=http://chatychaty.com/2013/01/neigh-burger-king-finally-admits-it-has-been-selling-beef-burgers-containing-horsemeat/|date=31 January 2013}}</ref> after horse meat was found in their supply chain.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2013/jan/31/burger-king-horsemeat|title=Burger King reveals its burgers were contaminated in horsemeat scandal | work= The Guardian|accessdate=25 February 2013|location=London|first1=James|last1=Meikle|first2=Felicity|last2=Lawrence|first3=Jemma|last3=Buckley|date=31 January 2013}}</ref>
[[Waitrose]] removed beef meatballs from sale when it found that they contained pork. The meatballs were manufactured by an ABP factory in [[Glasgow]]. Waitrose, part of [[John Lewis (department store)|John Lewis]], said it would be creating a new facility to supply its own beef products.<ref>{{cite news|title='Pork' meatballs withdrawn by Waitrose made in Glasgow factory|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-21442328|accessdate=14 February 2013|date=13 February 2013|work=BBC News}}</ref>
Tesco, [[the Co-operative Group]] and Aldi also cancelled contracts with ABP Food Group because of the adulteration.<ref name=Waitrose>{{cite news|work=The Irish Independent |url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/waitrose-ditches-burgers-linked-to-irish-firm-3367350.html |title=Waitrose ditches burgers linked to Irish firm |date=26 January 2013 |first=Aideen |last=Sheehan |accessdate=26 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DxeSqd8l?url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/waitrose-ditches-burgers-linked-to-irish-firm-3367350.html |archivedate=26 January 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name=BurgerKing>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/horsemeat-issue-sees-burger-king-drop-irish-supplier-3363141.html |title=Horsemeat issue sees Burger King drop Irish supplier |work=The Irish Independent |date=23 January 2013 |accessdate=26 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DxeXe3KV?url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/horsemeat-issue-sees-burger-king-drop-irish-supplier-3363141.html |archivedate=26 January 2013 |first=Aideen |last=Sheehan |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name=Sorry>{{cite news|work=The Irish Times |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2013/0131/1224329468253.html |title=Silvercrest says sorry after loss of contracts with two supermarket chains |date=31 January 2013 |accessdate=31 January 2013 |deadurl=no |last=Healy |first=Alison |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6E5Ai2rDO?url=https://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2013/0131/1224329468253.html |archivedate=31 January 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Food wholesaler [[Makro]], supplier to the restaurant and pub industry,<ref>{{cite news|last=Harrington|first=John|title=Makro withdraws selected frozen burgers after horse meat scare|url=http://www.morningadvertiser.co.uk/Pub-Chef/Makro-withdraws-selected-frozen-burgers-after-horse-meat-scare|work=The Publican's Morning Advertiser|accessdate=14 February 2013|date=17 January 2013}}</ref> announced that some of its frozen burgers supplied by Silvercrest tested positive for horse DNA. A spokesman said that Makro no longer sold the product in question.<ref>{{cite news|title=Horsemeat scandal: FSA inquiry 'will be relentless'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21437328|accessdate=14 February 2013|date=13 February 2013|work=BBC News}}</ref>
=== Spanghero === On 14 February 2013, the French government stated that French meat processing company [[À la Table de Spanghero]] knowingly sold horse meat labelled as beef, and that their licence was suspended while an inquiry continues.<ref name="bbc_blame">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-21464052|title=Horsemeat scandal: France blames processor Spanghero|date=14 February 2013|accessdate=14 February 2013|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> Spanghero imported meat from Romania and sold it on to another French company, [[Comigel]], which made frozen ready meals at its factory in Luxembourg. French Consumer Affairs Minister [[Benoît Hamon]] said the meat had left Romania clearly and correctly labelled as horse and that it was afterwards that it was relabelled as beef by Spanghero.<ref name="bbc_blame"/> The investigation also said some blame may rest with Comigel, claiming the staff there should have noticed anomalies in the paperwork, and realised from the smell and look of the meat once it was defrosted that it was not beef.<ref name="bbc_blame"/>
=== Comigel === On 7 February 2013, [[Findus]] announced that in a sample of 18 beef [[lasagne]] products that it tested, 11 contained between 60% and 100% horse meat.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lawrence|first=Felicity|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/feb/07/findus-beef-lasagne-horse-meat |title=Findus beef lasagne withdrawn after tests show high level of horsemeat |work=The Guardian |accessdate=9 February 2013|location=London|date=7 February 2013}}</ref> It was also revealed that some of the products sold had minced meat declared as beef that was 60–100% horse meat.<ref name=Sky1049133>{{cite news |url=http://news.sky.com/story/1049133/some-findus-lasagne-meals-were-100-percent-horsemeat |title= Findus Beef Lasagne Meals 100% Horsemeat |work=Sky News |date=8 February 2013 |accessdate=7 February 2013}}</ref> The source of the horse meat was third party supplier Comigel, a French-headquartered frozen ready meal producer, from its subsidiary [[Tavola]] factory in [[Capellen]], Luxembourg. According to the FSA the company had been alerted by a third-party French supplier on 4 February 2013, and tested its beef lasagne products finding over 50% of the tested products contained horse meat. According to reports both Findus UK and the French supplier withdrew all products related to the third party supplier. The reason for the adulteration was initially stated as "highly likely" criminal activity.<ref name=bbc_nospec>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21377601 |title= Horsemeat scandal: Don't dump meat, says food minister |date=8 February 2013 |accessdate=8 February 2013|work=BBC News}}</ref>
The president of Comigel, Erick Lehagre, told [[Agence France-Presse]] that the adulterated meat supplier was Spanghero, a firm owned by [[Lur Berri]] and founded in 1970 by [[Claude Spanghero|Claude]] and Laurent Spanghero, two former France international rugby players.<ref name="tg_ecoli">{{cite news|title=French firm supplying horse meat was previously at centre of E.coli scare|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/foodanddrinknews/9859412/French-firm-supplying-horse-meat-was-previously-at-centre-of-E.coli-scare.html|date=9 February 2013|accessdate=14 February 2013|last1=Sawer|first1=Patrick|last2=Ensor|first2=Josie|location=London|work=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref> He said that Spanghero had told him that the meat was not from France, but came from a producer in Romania.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lasagnes à la viande de cheval : une fraude à l'échelle européenne|url=http://www.liberation.fr/monde/2013/02/08/du-cheval-roumain-dans-les-lasagnes-findus_880511|work=Libération|accessdate=14 February 2013|date=8 February 2013}}</ref> On 11 February 2013 France's Consumer Affairs Minister Benoit Hamon warned it "will not hesitate" to take legal action if there is evidence companies had knowingly duped consumers. Hamon said an initial investigation by French safety authorities had found a French company [[Poujol]] (Spanghero's holding company) bought frozen meat from a Cypriot trader. That trader had bought it from Dutch food supplier Draap (the Dutch word for horse, ''Paard'' spelled backwards), owned by Jan Fasen, who was previously convicted for horse meat fraud in 2007.<ref name=GuardHME/> Draap, in turn, bought it from two Romanian slaughterhouses.<ref name=GuardHME/> Poujol then supplied a factory in Luxembourg, owned by Comigel, which then supplied Findus and the British supermarkets. The Romanian government has stated that there are no contracts between the Romanian abattoirs and any French, Cypriot or Dutch meat processors.<ref>{{cite news|title=Horsemeat Legal Action Starts in Europe|url=http://news.sky.com/story/1050378/horsemeat-legal-action-starts-in-europe|work=Sky News|accessdate=12 February 2013|date=11 February 2013}}</ref>
On 8 February 2013, Findus announced that it would no longer accept meat from Comigel, and stopped further deliveries of the product in question. On the same day, Findus UK published a public apology on its website, also announcing that, following DNA testing, three of its products were found to contain horse tissue. These are the 320, 350 and 500 gram packages of Findus Beef Lasagne; the company offered a refund for products purchased.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.findus.co.uk/ |title=Findus UK | Good Food Made Findusly Simple! |publisher=Findus.co.uk |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=9 February 2013}}</ref> Findus Sverige AB also announced a recall of its {{nowrap|375 gram}} packs of ready-made single-portion lasagne (code 63957), and published a contact number for customers who had already purchased the products.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mynewsdesk.com/se/pressroom/findus/pressrelease/view/findus-aaterkallar-1-portion-lasagne-375-gram-artikelnummer-63957-835305 |title=Findus Sverige AB – Findus återkallar 1-portion Lasagne, 375 gram, artikelnummer 63957 |work=mynewsdesk.com |accessdate=9 February 2013}}</ref> On 8 February 2013 supermarket chain Aldi announced that it would withdraw from sale Today's Special Frozen Beef Lasagne and Today's Special Frozen Spaghetti Bolognese, supplied by Comigel, after tests found the meat content to be between 30 and 100% horse.
=== HJ Schypke === The Swiss-based company [[Nestlé]] reported on 18 February 2013 that it had found more than 1% horse DNA in two beef pasta products. It withdrew chilled pasta products, Buitoni Beef Ravioli and Beef Tortellini, in Italy and Spain.<ref name=bbc_nestle/><ref name=guardian_nestle/> Sourced from sub-contractor HJ Schypke, itself a German sub-contractor of Belgian-based Nestlé supplier JBS Toledo,<ref name=bbc_nestle/> also withdrew frozen Lasagnes à la Bolognaise Gourmandes, a product for catering businesses produced in France.<ref name=bbc_nestle>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21501568|title=Nestle removes beef pasta meals after finding horsemeat|work=BBC News|date=18 February 2013|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref> <ref name=guardian_nestle>{{cite news|title=Nestlé finds horsemeat in pasta meals|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/feb/19/nestle-horsemeat-in-pasta-products|accessdate=19 February 2013|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=19 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nestle.com/media/statements/supplier-mislabeled-beef-horse-meat|title=Supplier found to have mislabeled beef|publisher=[[Nestlé]]|date=18 February 2013|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref>
=== Frigilunch === On 22 February 2013, [[Birds Eye]] revealed that DNA tests showed that horse meat was present in Birds Eye [[chili con carne]] sold in Belgium and supplied by Belgium firm [[Frigilunch]].<ref name=beeb>{{cite news|title=Horsemeat scandal: Birds Eye withdraws UK ready meals|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21543158|accessdate=22 February 2013|work=BBC News|date=22 February 2013}}</ref> Birds Eye withdrew three ready meals that contained beef from sale in the UK.<ref name=beeb/>
=== Sodexo === All of the frozen beef products produced by [[Sodexo]], "one of the largest private catering businesses in Britain",<ref name=graun>{{cite news|last=Meikle|first=James|title=Horsemeat scandal: schools caterer suspends all frozen beef products|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/feb/22/horsemeat-scandal-schools-frozen-beef|accessdate=23 February 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=22 February 2013|location=London}}</ref> were withdrawn on 22 February 2013 following the discovery of horse DNA in a sample.<ref name=graun/> The company supplies 2,300 institutions within the UK, including schools, old-age people homes, prisons and branches of the armed forces .<ref name=graun/>
=== Kuršu Zeme === On 1 March the Department of Food and Veterinary of [[Lithuania]] announced that horse meat was found in three [[Canning|canned]] beef brands sold by Latvian company Kuršu Zeme.<ref name="delfi_arklienos">{{cite web|title=Arklienos rasta "Turistų pusryčiuose" ir kituose konservuose |url=http://verslas.delfi.lt/verslas/arklienos-rasta-turistu-pusryciuose-ir-kituose-konservuose.d?id=60808575|date=1 March 2013|accessdate=2 March 2013|publisher=verslas.delfi.lt}}</ref> Canned beef made by the Latvian company was removed from sale in Lithuania.<ref name="delfi_maxima">{{cite web|title="Maxima" iš prekybos šalina latviškus konservus, tiriamus dėl arklienos |url=http://verslas.delfi.lt/verslas/maxima-is-prekybos-salina-latviskus-konservus-tiriamus-del-arklienos.d?id=60801823 |date=28 February 2013|accessdate=2 March 2013|publisher=verslas.delfi.lt}}</ref>
=== Wiljo Import en Export B.V. and Vleesgroothandel Willy Selten B.V. === On 10 April 2013, it was reported that two Dutch trading companies owned by the same person who had previously been investigated by food safety officials may have supplied {{nowrap|50 000 metric tonnes}} of adulterated beef containing horse meat since January 2011.<ref name="bbc_world">{{cite news|title=Horsemeat scandal: Dutch uncover large-scale meat fraud|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22098763|date=10 April 2013|accessdate=10 April 2013|work=BBC News}}</ref>
===Findus=== On 7 February 2013, it was revealed by the [[Food Standards Agency]] that the Findus beef [[lasagne]] range in the UK, France and Sweden and the shepherd's pie and moussaka ranges in France contained [[horse meat]] without proper declaration or official scrutiny .<ref name=bbcconf/><ref>{{cite web|title=Aimez-vous les lasagnes au cheval roumain?|url=http://sosconso.blog.lemonde.fr/2013/02/10/aimez-vous-les-lasagnes-au-cheval-roumain/}} 10 February 2013 lemonde.fr</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Food safety watchdog may report Findus |url=http://www.thelocal.se/46112/20130210/#.URgCAqWZodI |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130926022308/http://www.thelocal.se/46112/20130210 |archivedate=26 September 2013 |df= }}2013-02-10 thelocal.se</ref> The contamination may have gone on since summer 2012 according to a leaked document.<ref name="idsum">{{cite news|title=Horsemeat scandal: Findus leak reveals horse in ‘beef’ for six months|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/horsemeat-scandal-findus-leak-reveals-horse-in-beef-for-six-months-8486602.html | location=London | work=The Independent|first=Martin|last=Hickman|date=9 February 2013}} 9 February 2013 independent.co.uk</ref>
===Compass Group=== [[Compass Group]] was the world's biggest catering firm at the time and discovered through conducting tests that it was unknowingly supplying concealed horse meat in food products to a "small number" of schools in Northern Ireland.<ref name="reuters">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/retailandconsumer/9873300/Compass-nd-Whitbread-caught-up-in-horse-meat-scandal.html|title=Compass and Whitbread caught up in horse meat scandal|author=Reuters|date=15 February 2013|work=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref><ref name="reuters.com">{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/02/15/us-horsemeat-britain-idUSBRE91E0NT20130215|title=Compass, Whitbread drawn into horsemeat scandal|work=reuters.com}}</ref><ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21476736|title=Horsemeat: Compass and Whitbread find horse DNA in products|work=BBC News}}</ref><ref name="bbc.co.uk1">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21468699|title=Horsemeat scandal: Supermarkets 'share anger and outrage'|work=BBC News}}</ref><ref name="Catering & Hospitality News">{{cite web|url=https://www.thecaterer.com/articles/347463/caterers-reassure-over-supply-chain-as-minister-brands-horse-meat-scandal-wholly-unacceptable |title=Catering & Hospitality News |publisher=Thecaterer.com |date= |accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="paulowen">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/blog/2013/feb/15/horsemeat-food-standards-agency-delivers-report-live-coverage|title=Horsemeat scandal: FSA raid three new premises|author=Paul Owen|work=the Guardian}}</ref>
===Whitbread=== [[Whitbread]], which was at the time Britain's biggest hotel group also discovered through tests that it had unknowingly sold concealed horse meat in food products.<ref name="reuters"/><ref name="reuters.com"/><ref name="bbc.co.uk"/><ref name="bbc.co.uk1"/><ref name="Catering & Hospitality News"/><ref name="paulowen"/>
== Source of meat == The horse meat that was found in Comigel products originated at Doly Com,<ref>{{cite news|title=Analyzing Horse Meat Scandal, Its Effects, and How it Progressed.|url=http://www.theworldreporter.com/2013/03/horse-meat-scandal-effects-and-progress.html|accessdate=4 March 2013|newspaper=The World Reporter|date=14 March 2013}}</ref> a Romanian-based [[slaughterhouse]]. An inquiry by the French government showed that "the meat had left Romania clearly and correctly labelled as horse. It was afterwards that it was relabelled as beef."<ref>{{cite news|title=Horsemeat scandal: France blames processor Spanghero|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-21464052|accessdate=17 February 2013|publisher=BBC News|date=14 February 2013}}</ref> Doly Com supplied the horse meat under a contract to [[Cyprus]]-based Draap Trading Ltd, a meat trader which operates in the Netherlands. It is owned by a [[British Virgin Islands]] holding company, and Jan Fasen is a director. ''Draap'' spelt backwards is ''paard,'' the [[Dutch language|Dutch]] word for ''horse''.<ref name=GuardFasen>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/feb/13/horsemeat-scandal-dutch-connection-romania|title=Horsemeat scandal: Dutch meat trader could be central figure|work=The Guardian|date=13 February 2013|accessdate=18 February 2013|location=London|first1=Luke|last1=Harding|first2=Ian|last2=Traynor}}</ref> After having the horse meat delivered to a cold storage company in [[Breda]], Draap then sold the frozen meat to Spanghero,<ref name="jptimes">{{cite web|title=First legal suits are filed over horse-meat fraud |work=Japan Times |url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2013/02/11/business/first-legal-suits-are-filed-over-horse-meat-fraud/|date=11 February 2013}}</ref> who insist that it arrived at their [[Castelnaudary]] plant labelled as "Beef – originating in EU".<ref name=GuardHME/><ref name=GuardFasen/> After some processing, Spanghero then sent it to Comigel, where the end products for sale were made.<ref name="tg_ecoli"/><ref name=GuardHME/> According to French media reports, Spanghero falsified documents regarding the meat.<ref name="tl_watchdog">{{cite web|title=Food safety watchdog may report Findus |url=http://www.thelocal.se/46112/20130210/ |date=10 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130926022308/http://www.thelocal.se/46112/20130210 |archivedate=26 September 2013 |df= }}</ref>
Horse meat found in Silvercrest products is thought to have originated in Poland.<ref>{{cite news |last=Driver |first=Alistair |url=http://www.farmersguardian.com/abp-sourced-contaminated-polish-horse-meat-from-irish-trader/53224.article |title=ABP sourced contaminated Polish horse meat from Irish trader |work=Farmers Guardian |accessdate=17 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130210071733/http://www.farmersguardian.com/abp-sourced-contaminated-polish-horse-meat-from-irish-trader/53224.article |archivedate=10 February 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== Health implications== A small survey, part of the EU-funded project FoodRisC, by a team from [[University College Dublin]] and [[Brunel University]] found that health risks were not respondents' first concern, but rather that the claims made on labels did not match the contents of food products.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishhealth.com/article.html?id=21730 |title=Horse meat health risks 'not a concern', 21 February 2013 |publisher=irishhealth.com |accessdate=11 April 2013}}</ref> Additional concerns included allegations that a "French plant which handled horse meat sold in Britain as beef has previously been at the centre of a major [[E.coli]] discovery".<ref name="telegraph1">{{cite news|last1=Watts|first1=Robert|last2=Sawer|first2=Patrick|last3=Donnelly|first3=Laura|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/foodanddrinknews/9859946/Horse-meat-scandal-More-contaminated-food-likely-to-be-found.html|title=Horse meat scandal: 'More contaminated food likely to be found'|work=The Telegraph|date=9 February 2013|accessdate=14 February 2013|location=London}}</ref> Inquiry into horse meat sources in the UK also revealed that [[Aintree racecourse]] has a contract with a licensed slaughterhouse in West Yorkshire to remove dead [[Grand National]] race horses. It is illegal for horses [[animal euthanasia|euthanised]] by injection to be put into the human food chain.<ref name=bbc14feb/> Many chemical agents used for animal euthanasia leave residues in the meat which may be harmful to humans, and have caused sickness and death in animal predators and scavengers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.avma.org/KB/Policies/Documents/euthanasia.pdf |title= AVMA Guidelines on Euthanasia|publisher= AVMA Panel on Euthanasia|page=18|date= June 2007|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref> Aintree officials stated they were "as confident as we possibly can be that no unfit meat ever reaches the human food chain."<ref name=bbc14feb/>
=== Phenylbutazone === In January 2013, concerns first arose about the possibility that horse meat containing traces of the veterinary drug [[phenylbutazone]] could enter the human food chain,<ref name=bbc_nospec/><ref name="idsum" /> in spite of regulations that horses treated with it cannot legally be used for human consumption.<ref name=McGrath>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21383362 | title=UK vets have 'repeatedly raised concerns' over bute in food |date=8 February 2013 |accessdate=15 February 2013|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> The drug, commonly known as "bute", is used as an [[analgesic]] in horses.<ref name=McGrath/> The issue was also raised by politicians such as Labour party MP [[Mary Creagh]].<ref name=Molloy>{{cite web|last=Molloy |first=Mark |url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/01/24/fresh-fears-over-cancer-drug-found-in-horse-meat-3365221/ |title=Horse meat burger scandal: 'Carcinogen phenylbutazone found in meat' | Metro News |work=Metro|location=UK |date=24 January 2013 |accessdate=15 February 2013}}</ref>
In response, the [[Food Standards Agency]] (FSA) initially stated that there had been only five cases of slaughtered horses in the UK which had been treated with phenylbutazone, none of which had entered the human food chain.<ref name=Molloy/> A subsequent review of 206 horse carcasses slaughtered in the UK between 30 January and 7 February 2013 found eight were contaminated with phenylbutazone, six of which had been shipped to France.<ref name=bbc14feb>{{cite news|author=James Gallagher |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21455419 |title=Horsemeat scandal: Bute found in eight horse carcasses |publisher=BBC |date=14 February 2013 |accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref> The UK's [[Chief Medical Officer]], [[Sally Davies (doctor)|Sally Davies]], said the level of contamination, 1.9 mg/kg, posed "very little risk to human health".<ref name=bbc14feb/> She added that around 500–600 burgers containing 100% horse meat would need to be eaten to receive the daily human therapeutic dose.<ref name=cmo>{{cite news|author=Sally Davies, England's chief medical officer |url=http://www.foodmanufacture.co.uk/Food-Safety/Horse-meat-health-officials-reassure-as-bute-carcasses-sent-to-France-again |title=Horse meat: health officials reassure as bute carcasses sent to France – again |date=14 February 2013 |accessdate=14 February 2013}}</ref> Additional tests at that time indicated than none of the products from Findus contained phenylbutazone.<ref name=bbc14feb/> Another report found that between two and five percent of samples tested between 2007 and 2011 had phenylbutazone contamination, and that only 50 samples per year were tested. In 2012, 145 carcasses had been tested, and two out of the nine carcasses found positive for bute that year were not reported to the FSA for seven months.<ref name=Guardian14Feb>{{cite news|author1=Damian Carrington |author2=James Meikle |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/feb/14/horsemeat-scandal-bute-food-chain |title=Horsemeat scandal deepens as minister says bute may be in food chain | ''The Guardian''. |work=The Guardian |date=14 February 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2013 |location=London}}</ref> In April 2013, the FSA reported it had not only found more than 1% horse DNA in [[Asda]]'s {{nowrap|340 gram}} tins of {{nowrap|"Smart Price Corned Beef"}} but it also contained four [[Parts-per notation#Parts-per expressions|ppb]] of phenylbutazone, marking the first time since the start of the scandal that bute had been detected in a meat product in the UK food chain.<ref name="bbc_asda_bute">{{cite news|title=Veterinary drug found in Asda budget corned beef|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22087123|date=9 April 2013|accessdate=10 April 2013|publisher=BBC}}</ref><ref name="fsa_asda_bute">{{cite web|title=Food Standards Agency – Very low levels of bute found in Asda 'Smart Price Corned Beef'|url=http://www.food.gov.uk/news-updates/news/2013/apr/asda-bute|date=9 April 2013|accessdate=10 April 2013|publisher=food.gov.uk}}</ref>
However, one problem raised was over documentation; all of the UK animals with phenylbutazone contamination tested in early 2013 possessed a "[[horse passport]]" that allowed the carcasses to be sold for human consumption.<ref name=bbc14feb/> The veterinary residues committee (VRC) reminded the public in July 2012 that it had been "repeatedly expressing concern" about phenylbutazone contamination.<ref name=Guardian13Feb>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/feb/11/tesco-spaghetti-bolognese-horsemeat |title=Tesco says some of its value spaghetti bolognese contains 60% horsemeat |work=The Guardian |accessdate=11 April 2013 |location=London |first1=Simon |last1=Neville |first2=James |last2=Meikle |first3=Damian |last3=Carrington |first4=Luke |last4=Harding |date=11 February 2013}}</ref> and recent discoveries of contamination suggest that the passport system was not working.<ref name=Guardian14Feb/>
Phenylbutazone is used therapeutically in humans as a treatment for [[ankylosing spondylitis]]<ref>[http://www.iow.nhs.uk/index.asp?record=1655 NHS: Drugs used in Rheumatic Diseases and Gout, 2012] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130429161039/http://www.iow.nhs.uk/index.asp?record=1655 |date=29 April 2013 }}: "PHENYLBUTAZONE (Named patient only, for the treatment of ankylosing spondylitis)"</ref> when other treatments are not suitable.<ref name=McGrath/> The effect on humans of low-level exposure over an extended period has not been extensively formally studied. High incidences of focal [[necrosis]] were found in female rats fed low doses of [[1,2-diphenylhydrazine]] over time.<!--p28/83--><ref name="cdc_tp136">{{cite web|title=empty|url=http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprofiles/tp136.pdf|date=27 January 2012|accessdate=15 February 2013|publisher=atsdr.cdc.gov}}</ref> Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) residues risk causing rare, but potentially fatal side-effects in humans.<ref name="twycrosszoo_phenylbutazone">{{cite web|title=Phenylbutazone (NSAID) (Chemical Page)|url=http://wildpro.twycrosszoo.org/S/00Chem/ChComplex/Phenylbutazone.htm|date=2 January 2011|accessdate=15 February 2013|publisher=wildpro.twycrosszoo.org|quote=A non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) commonly used for the treatment of musculoskeletal disorders in horses. Effective in ruminants but generally prohibited for use in food-producing animals due to risks of residues causing rare but potentially fatal side-effects in humans.}}</ref> There is inadequate data on [[carcinogenicity]] of phenylbutazone; it is not classifiable as to its carcinogenicity to humans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toxnet.nlm.nih.gov/cgi-bin/sis/search/a?dbs+hsdb:@term+@DOCNO+3159 |title=Phenylbutazone – National Library of Medicine HSDB Database |publisher=Toxnet.nlm.nih.gov |accessdate=15 February 2013}}</ref>
There is also speculation that some horse meat from the United States, where phenylbutazone is commonly used, may have entered the food chain via Mexico and then been exported to Europe.<ref>{{cite web|author=James Forsyth |url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/columnists/politics/8844521/the-horsemeat-scandal-shows-the-true-extent-of-europes-power-in-britain/ |title=The horsemeat scandal shows the true extent of Europe's power in Britain |work=The Spectator |accessdate=15 February 2013}}</ref> One reason for this is that Spanghero had purchased meat from a company, Draap, whose owner, Jan Fasen was previously convicted for fraud; as long ago as 2007, Draap had labelled horse meat imported from Mexico and South America as Dutch or German beef.<ref name=GuardHME>{{cite news| last=Lawrence|first=Felicity| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/feb/15/horsemeat-scandal-the-essential-guide |title=Horsemeat scandal: the essential guide |accessdate=15 February 2013| location=London|date=15 February 2013|work=The Guardian}}</ref> The primary concern is horse meat from the United States: up to 15% of horses sent to slaughter in Canada or Mexico are former racehorses that have been given drugs during their racing career, such as phenylbutazone, which are approved for use in horses but not humans and carry the warning "Do not use in horses intended for human consumption." Further, they are given medication at levels that led a research veterinarian to call them "walking pharmacies". These animals may have meat too toxic to eat safely.<ref name=NYTDec2012>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/09/sports/drugs-injected-at-the-racetrack-put-europe-off-us-horse-meat.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1&|title=Racetrack Drugs Put Europe Off U.S. Horse Meat|author=Joe Drape|date=8 December 2012|location=Paris|page=A1|work=The New York Times}}</ref>
===Equine infectious anaemia=== Some experts and UK government officials have raised concerns that horse meat from Romania could be contaminated with [[equine infectious anaemia]] (EIA).<ref name="telegraph1"/> Although EIA does not pose a risk to humans, it could be an indicator of additional health problems in horses that may stem from poor living conditions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2013/02/12/hors-f12.html |title=UK horsemeat scandal spreads to Europe – World Socialist Web Site |publisher=Wsws.org |accessdate=15 February 2013}}</ref> Since 2007, the European Union has restricted export of live horses from Romania to any other EU member state unless the animals have a [[Coggins test]] for EIA prior to export.<ref name=defra_esi>{{cite web|title=Equine infectious anaemia (Swamp fever)|url=http://www.defra.gov.uk/animal-diseases/a-z/equine-infectious-anaemia/|publisher=Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs|accessdate=13 February 2013|date=1 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Commission decision of 23 April 2007 on protective measures with regard to equine infectious anaemia in Romania |url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2007/l_115/l_11520070503en00180019.pdf |accessdate=13 February 2013|date=2 May 2007}}</ref> Environment secretary [[Owen Paterson]] stated that "Romanian horse meat is not allowed in", though he acknowledged that it could be a serious problem if Romanian horse meat from animals with EIA had been imported.<ref name="guardianWatt"/>
Some news outlets referred to EIA as "Horse AIDS",<ref name="telegraph1"/><ref name="guardianWatt">{{cite news|author=Nicholas Watt, chief political correspondent |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2013/feb/10/contaminated-horsemeat-harm-health?INTCMP=SRCH |title=Contaminated horsemeat could harm health, warns environment secretary | Society |work=The Guardian |accessdate=5 March 2013 |location=London |date=10 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/foodanddrinknews/9859915/Horse-meat-scandal-How-horses-slaughtered-in-Romania-end-up-on-British-plates.html |title=Horse meat scandal: How horses slaughtered in Romania end up on British plates |work=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=5 March 2013 |location=London |first=Patrick |last=Sawer |date=10 February 2013}}</ref> even though it is not an immunodeficiency syndrome and the [[retrovirus]] that causes it is equid-specific.<ref name=Merck>{{cite web|url=http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/52800.htm |title=Merck Veterinary Manual |publisher=Merckvetmanual.com |accessdate=25 February 2013}}</ref> EIA is, however, a [[lentivirus]], like HIV,<ref>{{cite journal|title= Equine infectious anemia virus gag and pol genes: relatedness to visna and AIDS virus| pmid=3003905 | volume=231 | year=1986| journal=Science| pages=589–94 | last1 = Stephens | first1 = RM | last2 = Casey | first2 = JW | last3 = Rice | first3 = NR | doi=10.1126/science.3003905}}</ref> and thus research on EIA has the potential to help research efforts with HIV/AIDS.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/rare-horses-in-eiahiv-research-rescued-from-dangerous-4500-mile-journey-127725748.html |title=Rare Horses in EIA/HIV Research Rescued From Dangerous 4,500-Mile Journey |agency=PR Newswire |date=15 August 2011 |accessdate=15 February 2013}}</ref>
==Contributory causes== An article by [[Will Hutton]] about contamination in the UK lays much of the responsibility at the door of those who have (in the name of relaxing stifling [[red tape]]) removed much of the regulation of the meat industry, and cut the budgets and workforces—halving the number of inspectors—of those responsible for enforcing the remaining regulations.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/feb/17/horsemeat-scandal-is-tory-party-crisis |title=The Observer newspaper: The meat scandal shows all that is rotten about our free marketeers. 17 February 2013 |work=The Guardian |date=4 February 2012 |accessdate=24 February 2013 |location=London |first=Will |last=Hutton}}</ref> Another article points out that "Long business supply chains are corruptible and can hide a multitude of crimes if no one checks for fraud or criminal activity".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/foodanddrinknews/9870692/Slavery-not-horse-meat-is-the-real-scandal-on-our-doorstep.html |title=The Telegraph newspaper, article about horsemeat scandal, and also lack of enforcement facilitating exploitation of trafficked humans, 14 February 2013 |work=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=24 February 2013 |location=London |first=Fraser |last=Nelson |date=14 February 2013}}</ref>
In Britain, the incident was a catalyst for the discussion of the validity of a [[Industry self-regulation|self-regulated]] meat industry. Karen Jennings, assistant general secretary of the [[UNISON]] [[trades union]], said that "the industry isn't fit to regulate itself".<ref>{{cite news|last=Meikle|first=James|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jan/16/horsemeat-burgers-scandal-food-hygiene |title=Horsemeat-in-burgers scandal prompts food hygiene fears |work=The Guardian |date=16 January 2013 |accessdate=22 January 2013|location=London}}</ref>
== Implications for religious groups == Observant [[Islamic dietary laws|Muslims]] and [[Kashrut|Jews]] consider it [[sin]]ful to eat certain types of meat, pork for both groups and also horse and many other animals for Jews, due to religious prohibitions. Professor Reilly stated "for some religious groups or people who abstain from eating pig meat, the presence of traces of pig DNA is unacceptable".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/15/horsemeat-found-in-burgers_n_2482990.html |title=Horsemeat Found in Burger in Ireland |work=Huffington Post |accessdate=22 January 2013 |date=15 January 2013}}</ref> On 15 March 2013 it was confirmed by a Westminister wing on Health and Safety that pig DNA had been found in halal chicken sausages produced for schools.<ref>{{cite news|title=Halal school sausages contained pork DNA, Westminster survey found|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/mar/14/school-halal-sausages-pork-dna|accessdate=15 March 2013|date=14 March 2013|location=London|work=The Guardian}}</ref>
== Reactions == [[File:'Neigh horse in our burgers!', Swan and Talbot, Wetherby (15th February 2013).JPG|thumb|right|upright|'Neigh horse in our burgers', a satire on the scandal outside a pub in [[Wetherby]], West Yorkshire.]] Horse meat is not normally eaten in Ireland and Britain. According to Professor Reilly, chief executive of the FSAI, "In Ireland, it is not our culture to eat horse meat and therefore, we do not expect to find it in a burger".<ref name="id_pigburger">{{cite news|author=George Hook: |url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/horse-and-pig-dna-found-in-some-supermarket-burgers-3354449.html |title=Horse and pig DNA found in some supermarket burgers – National News |work=The Irish Independent |date=15 January 2013|accessdate=16 January 2013}}</ref> Silvercrest, a subsidiary of ABP Foods has claimed that there is no risk to the public upon eating the foreign meat.<ref name="id_asdaclear">{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Rob|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/asda-clears-shelves-of-value-burgers-as-horsemeat-scandal-knocks-300m-off-tesco-market-value-8453499.html |title=Asda clears shelves of value burgers as horsemeat scandal knocks £300m off Tesco market value |work=The Independent |date=16 January 2013 |accessdate=22 January 2013|location=London}}</ref> Eleven firms, including [[Tesco]] and [[Asda]], said they shared shoppers' "anger and outrage".<ref name="bbc.co.uk1" /> Whitbread vowed to remedy the unacceptable situation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2013/feb/26/whitbread-food-chain-horsemeat-scandal|title=Whitbread makes food pledge after horsemeat scandal|work=the Guardian}}</ref> The Food Standards Agency's (FSA) chief executive, [[Catherine Brown (FSA CE)|Catherine Brown]] also said "it is unlikely we will ever know" how many unwittingly ate horsemeat.<ref name="bbc.co.uk"/>
Tesco's market value dropped by {{nowrap|€360 million}}.<ref name=id_tescodrop>{{cite news|author=2013 Sports Calendar |url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/other-sports/horse-meat-discovery-knocks-300m-off-the-value-of-tesco-shares-3355157.html |title=Horse meat discovery knocks £300m off the value of Tesco shares – Other Sports, Sport |work=The Irish Independent |accessdate=22 January 2013}}</ref>
=== European Union officials === European Union officials, European ministers and Commissioner (Tonio) Borg set up an urgent meeting in [[Brussels]] on 13 February 2013 on how to contain the horse meat scandal that exposed flaws in European control systems on food safety, and to formulate an action plan.<ref name="rt_eumeet">{{cite news|title=EU ministers to hold meeting on horsemeat|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/02/12/uk-britain-food-horsemeat-idUKBRE91B13R20130212|date=12 February 2013 | work=Reuters}}</ref> Following the meeting, EU agriculture ministers announced a three-month programme of DNA testing of [[Meat#Additives|processed meat]] across the European Union.<ref name="dw_test">{{cite web|title=EU ministers call for emergency testing amid horsemeat scandal|url=http://www.dw.de/eu-ministers-call-for-emergy-testing-amid-horsemeat-scandal/a-16597514|date=13 February 2013}}</ref> The plan calls for 2,500 random tests on processed food for horse DNA and 4,000 for phenylbutazone (bute), beginning in March 2013, with initial results announced on 15 April 2013. It is unclear why the testing could not start immediately as most of the evidence is still present. The scale of DNA tests in April and May would be decided later. [[The Hague]]-based [[Europol]] would handle co-ordination of the investigations among national authorities and any raids on premises as well as arrests on suspicion of criminal conspiracy to defraud.<ref name="huff_dna">{{cite web|title=Horse Meat Scandal: EU Proposes Three-Month DNA Testing|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2013/02/13/horse-meat-scandal-eu-agrees-dna-tests_n_2680204.html|date=13 February 2013}}</ref>
=== Sales drop === On 26 February 2013 it was announced that sales of frozen hamburgers had fallen by 43% and frozen ready meals by 13% from levels before the scandal. The study took place {{nowrap|21 January – 17 February.}}<!--17 Feb minus 4 weeks--><ref name="guardian_frozen">{{cite news|title=Frozen burger sales plunge 43% after horsemeat scandal ||url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/feb/26/frozen-burger-sales-fall-horsemeat-scandal|date=26 February 2013|accessdate=26 February 2013|work=The Guardian|location=London|first=Simon|last=Neville}}</ref> Sales of ''bona fide'' horse meat, on the other hand, increased in those EU countries where it is moderately common.
== Factories == {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="6" style="text-align: center;" | Table of factories that produced adulterated foods |- ! Parent company !! Factory name !! [[Health mark|Health mark (factory number)]] !! Address !! Location !! % of sample contaminated |- | rowspan = "3" style="text-align: center;" | ABP Food Group<ref name="TimesGoodman">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2013/0117/1224328953025.html |title=Monaghan firm involved in horse meat controversy is part of Goodman empire |first=Colm |last=Keena |date=17 January 2013 |accessdate=18 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DlNOfFno?url=https://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2013/0117/1224328953025.html |archivedate=18 January 2013 |work=The Irish Times |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> |- | [[Silvercrest Foods]] || IE 565 EC<ref name="FSAIResult">{{cite web|url=http://www.fsai.ie/uploadedFiles/News_Centre/Burger_results_2013_01.pdf |title=FSAI Burger test results |date=15 January 2013 |accessdate=18 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DlUSuwTs?url=http://www.fsai.ie/uploadedFiles/News_Centre/Burger_results_2013_01.pdf |archivedate=18 January 2013 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> || [[Ballybay]], [[County Monaghan]], Ireland || {{coord|54.1326|N|6.9070|W|display=inline|scale:5000}} || 29.1<ref name="TimesGoodman" /><ref name="FSAIResult" /> |- | [[Dalepak]] Hambleton || UK HN012 EC<ref name="FSAIResult" /> || [[Leeming Bar]] Industrial Estate, Northallerton, North Yorkshire, England || {{coord|54.3046|N|1.5664|W|display=inline|scale:5000}} || 0.1<ref name="FSAIResult" /> |- | style="text-align: center;" | [[Liffey Meats]] || Liffey Meats || IE 325 EC<ref name="FSAIResult" /> || [[Ballyjamesduff]], [[County Cavan]], Ireland || {{coord|53.8527|N|7.2065|W|display=inline|scale:5000}} || trace<ref name="FSAIResult" /> |- | style="text-align: center;" | [[Comigel]] || Tavola || – || [[Capellen]], Luxembourg || {{coord|49.6479|N|5.9855|E|display=inline|scale:5000}} || 30–100<ref name=Sky1049133/> |}
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}}
== Arrests == On 23 May 2013, a Dutch meat wholesaler, Willy Selten, was arrested for allegedly selling 300 tonnes of horsemeat as beef. Selten, who owns the meat wholesaler Willy Selten BV, was arrested together with the company's interim director.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22639020 |title=Horsemeat scandal: Dutch trader Willy Selten arrested |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=23 May 2013 |accessdate=28 May 2014}}</ref> In October [[Barry Gardiner]] MP, the UK shadow Environment minister criticised the lack of prosecutions of leading players ten months after David Cameron promised that everything possible would be done to deal with a "very shocking" crime. Gardiner said "The extraordinary thing is that because of its clout, industry has been able to commit what appears to be a criminal offence – selling the public horsemeat falsely labelled as beef – and just say they are sorry and didn't know."<ref name=felicity>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/oct/22/horsemeat-scandal-guardian-investigation-public-secrecy|title=Where did the 29% horse in your Tesco burger come from?|work=The Guardian|date=22 October 2013|author=Felicity Lawrence|accessdate=22 October 2013}}</ref>
On 26 August 2016, three men were charged by the [[City of London Police]] with fraud offences relating to the sale of mixed beef and horsemeat products that were sold as beef between 1 January 2012 – 31 October 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Three men charged over UK horsemeat scandal|first=Jamie|last=Grierson|date=26 August 2016|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/aug/26/three-men-charged-over-uk-horsemeat-scandal|accessdate=27 August 2016}}</ref>
==December seizures==
In December 2013 consignments of horse meat were seized and arrests made. 21 people were arrested on Monday 16 December in various parts of the South of France. This meat was from horses that had been kept on a farm attached to a scientific laboratory, and was not certified as fit for human consumption. A dealer from [[Narbonne]] was helping police with enquiries.<ref name=Monde16Dec>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2013/12/16/demantelement-d-un-trafic-de-viande-de-cheval-dans-11-departements_4334831_3224.html |title=Viande de cheval : comprendre le nouveau scandale |publisher=Le Monde |date= |accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref>
== Timeline == {| class=wikitable |- ! Date !! Event |- | {{nowrap|2012 Summer}} || Adulteration may have started, according to a leaked document.<ref name="idsum"/> |- | 2012-11-30 || [[Food Safety Authority of Ireland|FSAI]] receives results from the [[Identigen laboratory]] on samples bought on {{nowrap|7–9}} November 2012, which were Salami products (19), beef meal products (31) and beef burger products (27). Where the quantitative test resulted in 23 (85%) beef burger products tested positive for porcine (pig) DNA and 10 (37%) beef burger products tested positive for equine (horse) DNA. The burgers came from {{nowrap|6 plants}} in Ireland and {{nowrap|3 plants}} in the UK. The products which tested positive for equine DNA came from {{nowrap|2 plants}} in Ireland and one in the UK.<ref name="ceo-statement"/> |- | 2012-12-07 || Irish authorities become aware of the adulteration in ABP Food Group burgers with 29% horse meat content.<ref name=id_withheld>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/coveney-struggles-to-contain-beef-crisis-as-results-withheld-3367353.html |title=Coveney struggles to contain beef crisis as results withheld |date=26 January 2013 |accessdate=26 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DxeHHe5n?url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/coveney-struggles-to-contain-beef-crisis-as-results-withheld-3367353.html |archivedate=26 January 2013 |work=Irish Independent |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> |- | 2012-12-10 || FSAI receives laboratory result from DNA sequencing confirms presence of equine (horse) and porcine (pig) DNA.<ref name="ceo-statement"/> |- | 2012-12-18 || FSAI receives laboratory confirmation on equine (horse) DNA from another round of purchased burger samples from 10 December from the same or similar product batches to the original samples that tested positive.<ref name="ceo-statement"/> |- | 2012-12-19 || FSAI receives result that the 10 burgers sampled on 7 to 9 November 2012, that tested positive for equine (horse) DNA were negative for the presence of [[phenylbutazone]] and other drugs.<ref name="ceo-statement"/> |- | 2013-01-11 || Samples that FSAI requested from [[Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine]] on 21 December, of raw ingredients from the two implicated meat processing plants in Ireland. And analysed by the Identigen laboratory on show of 4 January 2013ed very low or trace levels of equine (horse) DNA in beef products from the Netherlands, Spain and Ireland. However, they were not linked as ingredients.<ref name="ceo-statement"/><br> FSAI receives Semi-quantitative results from the Eurofins laboratory (Germany) that corroborates the initial results from the Identigen laboratory.<br> Quantitative results from Identigen lab indicates<!--src allusion on which lab is unclear--> that only {{nowrap|1 of 10}} burgers tests showed an estimated low 29% level of equine (horse) DNA. This product was manufactured by [[Lidl|Silvercrest]] on behalf of Tesco.<ref name="ceo-statement"/> |- | 2013-01-15 || The Food Safety Authority of Ireland (FSAI) announced that horse meat had been found in frozen beefburgers at several Irish and British supermarkets, including Tesco, Asda, Dunnes Stores, Lidl, Aldi and Iceland. The FSAI conducted tests on a selection of beef and salami products with "best before" dates between June 2012 and March 2014.<ref name="id_pigburger"/><br> FSAI advises the five retailers concerned ([[Tesco]], [[Dunnes Stores]], [[Aldi]], [[Lidl]] and [[Iceland (supermarket)|Iceland]]) of their findings. The implicated products are removed immediately.<ref name="ceo-statement"/> |- | 2013-01-16 || Tesco's market value dropped by {{nowrap|360 million EUR}}.<ref name=id_tescodrop/> |- | 2013-01-24 || Food Safety Authority of Ireland (FSAI) withheld 24 test results from a German laboratory.<ref name=id_withheld/> |- | 2013-01-29 || Samples that FSAI requested that HSE formally take from burgers in a range of retail and catering premises. Were analysed in the Eurofins laboratory under the direction of the HSE's public analyst. All tested negative except one which was a sample from [[Tesco]] that confirmed previous findings.<ref name="ceo-statement"/> |- | 2013-02-04 || Findus is alerted by a third party that the beef lasagne product did not "''conform to specification''"<ref name=bbc_nospec/> |- | 2013-02-07 || Revealed that Findus beef [[lasagne]] range in the UK, France and Sweden and the shepherd's pie and moussaka ranges in France contained horse meat without proper declaration.<ref name=bbcconf/><ref name="tl_watchdog"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Aimez-vous les lasagnes au cheval roumain?|url=http://sosconso.blog.lemonde.fr/2013/02/10/aimez-vous-les-lasagnes-au-cheval-roumain/|date=10 February 2013}}</ref> Out of 18 products 11 tested positive for horse meat.<ref name=bbcconf/> |- | 2013-02-08 || [[DGCCRF]] inspect Spanghero and was able to review the traceability of documents for the concerned batches on the past {{nowrap|4 months,}} which attests of the conformity of Spanghero's procedures.<ref name=it_enquete>{{cite web|title= Spanghero et Comigel, enquête de la répression des fraudes | i Télé | url=http://www.itele.fr/video/spanghero-et-comigel-enquete-de-la-repression-des-fraudes|date=11 February 2013}}</ref> |- | 2013-02-13 || European ministers and Commissioner (Tonio) Borg meets urgently in [[Brussels]].<ref name="rt_eumeet"/> |- | 2013-02-14 || DGCCRF investigation results become public, and determine the source of the fraud.<ref name=it_enquete/> On 14 February the French government put the blame on the French company [[À la Table de Spanghero|Spanghero]] but the company says it acted in good faith. The fraudulent sale shipped {{nowrap|750 [[ton]]}} of meat during {{nowrap|6 months.}}<ref name="bbc_blame"/> |- | 2013-02-14 || One 63-year-old man was arrested at Peter Boddy Licensed Slaughterhouse, in [[Todmorden]],<ref name=bbc_held>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21466074 |title=Three held in horsemeat mislabelling investigation |date=14 February 2013 |accessdate=15 February 2013|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> [[West Yorkshire]] and two men, aged 64 and 42, were held at Farmbox Meats Ltd, near [[Aberystwyth]],<ref name=bbc_held/> Wales, following searches by the [[Food Standards Agency]] (FSA) on 12 February 2013<ref name=bbc_3xarrest>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21464288 |title=Horsemeat scandal: Three men arrested on suspicion of fraud |accessdate=14 February 2013|publisher=BBC News |date=14 February 2013}}</ref> |- | 2013-02-25 || A study by [[Stellenbosch University]] found traces of [[water buffalo]], goat and donkey meat in various products on sale in South Africa.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.sun.ac.za/news/2013/02/25/sa-consumers-also-cheated-with-meat-products-su-study-finds/|title= SA consumers also cheated with meat products, SU study finds |date=25 February 2013 |accessdate=26 February 2013|publisher=Stellenbosch University}}</ref> |- | 2013-02-27 || Gæðakokkar 30% meat pie sold in [[Iceland (supermarket)|Iceland]] is found to not contain any meat at all.<ref name="gv_surprise">{{cite web|title=The Reykjavik Grapevine – News from Iceland / Surprising Twist in Horse Meat Scandal |url=http://www.grapevine.is/News/ReadArticle/Surprising-Twist-in-Horse-Meat-Scandal |date=28 February 2013 |accessdate=1 March 2013 |publisher=grapevine.is |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130304055742/http://www.grapevine.is/News/ReadArticle/Surprising-Twist-in-Horse-Meat-Scandal |archivedate=4 March 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref name="mast_nomeat">{{cite web|title=Fréttir – Matvælaöryggi|url=http://mast.is/frettaflokkar/frett/2013/02/27/Ekkert-kjot-i-nautaboku/|date=27 February 2013|accessdate=1 March 2013|publisher=mast.is}}</ref> |- | 2013-03-07 || One of two Russian suppliers of sausage to [[IKEA]] in Russia is found to contain horse meat despite its labelling.<ref name="mosc_ikea">{{cite web|title=IKEA suspends sausage sale in Russia due to horsemeat|url=http://themoscownews.com/business/20130307/191307398/IKEA-suspends-sausage-sale-in-Russia-due-to-horsemeat.html|date=7 March 2013|accessdate=7 March 2013|publisher=themoscownews.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130430171634/http://themoscownews.com/business/20130307/191307398/IKEA-suspends-sausage-sale-in-Russia-due-to-horsemeat.html|archive-date=30 April 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> |- | 2013-03-08 || Meat returned with green [[mould]] is cleaned, dried and resold in Polish plant to make sausages and ham. Exports to UK, Ireland, Germany and [[Lithuania]]. Three other Polish meat-processing plants were found to label horse meat as beef.<ref name="bbc_greenmeat">{{cite news|title=Poland plant halts production over rotten meat row|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21719372|date=8 March 2013|accessdate=9 March 2013|publisher=BBC}}</ref> |} (The [[Identigen laboratory|Identigen]] and [[Eurofins Scientific|Eurofin]] laboratories are both accredited to the European Standard EN [[ISO 17025|ISO/IEC 17025:2005]].{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}{{synthesis inline|date=March 2013}})
