{{pp-protected|reason=Persistent [[WP:Disruptive editing|disruptive editing]]|small=yes}} {{current event}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox college coach | name = Hugh Freeze | image = HughFreezeOM.jpg | sport = [[American football|Football]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1969|09|27}} | birth_place = [[Oxford, Mississippi]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = [[University of Southern Mississippi|Southern Mississippi]] | coach_years1 = 1992–1994 | coach_team1 = [[Briarcrest Christian School|Briarcrest (TN) HS]] ([[Offensive coordinator|OC]]/[[Defensive backs coach|DB]]) | coach_years2 = 1995–2004 | coach_team2 = Briarcrest (TN) HS | coach_years3 = 2006–2007 | coach_team3 = [[Ole Miss Rebels football|Ole Miss]] ([[Tight ends coach|TE]]/[[Recruiting coordinator|RC]]) | coach_years4 = 2008–2009 | coach_team4 = [[Lambuth Eagles football|Lambuth]] | coach_years5 = 2010 | coach_team5 = [[Arkansas State Red Wolves football|Arkansas State]] (OC) | coach_years6 = 2011 | coach_team6 = Arkansas State | coach_years7 = 2012–2016 | coach_team7 = [[Ole Miss]] | coach_years8 = 2018-present | coach_team8 = [[Arizona Hotshots]] (OC) | admin_years1 = 2005 | admin_team1 = [[Ole Miss Rebels|Ole Miss]] (assistant AD) | overall_record = 69–32 (college) | bowl_record = 3–1 | tournament_record = 1–2 (NAIA playoffs) | championships = 1 [[Sun Belt Conference|SunBelt]] (2011)
1 [[Mid-South Conference|Mid-South Conference West Division]] (2009)
2 Tennessee HS 8-AA (2002, 2004)
6 Tennessee HS 8-AA Regional (1995–1998, 2001, 2002) | awards = [[American Football Coaches Association|AFCA]] Southeast Region COY (2009)
Mid-South Conference COY (2009)
4× [[Associated Press|AP]] HS COY
5× Region 8-AA COY | coaching_records = }} '''Danny Hugh Freeze Jr.'''{{cite web|title=Nicholls coaching search nets 42 applicants |url=http://www.houmatoday.com/news/20091224/nicholls-coaching-search-nets-42-applicants|work=Houma Today|accessdate=December 14, 2013 |date=December 24, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131215023851/http://www.houmatoday.com/article/20091224/ARTICLES/912239867 |archivedate=December 15, 2013|deadurl=no}} (born September 27, 1969) is an [[American football]] coach. Freeze served as the head football coach at [[Lambuth University]] from 2008 to 2009 and at [[Arkansas State University]] in 2011. He was previously a successful high school football coach at [[Briarcrest Christian School]] in [[Memphis, Tennessee]], where he coached [[Michael Oher]] and [[Greg Hardy]]. He would later follow both of them to the University of Mississippi. ==Early life== Freeze attended [[Senatobia Municipal School District|Senatobia High School]] and the [[University of Southern Mississippi]], from which he graduated in 1992 with a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[mathematics]] and a minor in coaching and [[sports administration]].[http://www.astateredwolves.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=7200&ATCLID=204944063 Hugh Freeze Bio], Arkansas State University, retrieved December 16, 2010. ==Coaching career== ===Briarcrest Christian School=== In 1992, Freeze joined the staff at [[Briarcrest Christian School]] in [[Memphis, Tennessee]], as the football team's [[offensive coordinator]] and [[defensive backs coach]]. Freeze also served as dean of students.{{cite news|last1=Giannotto |first1=Mike|title=At Briarcrest Christian School, Hugh Freeze's legacy is everywhere |url=https://www.commercialappeal.com/story/sports/2017/07/24/briarcrest-christian-school-hugh-freezes-legacy-everywhere/506677001/ |work=The Commercial Appeal|date=July 24, 2017}} In 1995, he was promoted to head coach. Freeze ran the no huddle spread offense and led his team to the state championship twice, in 2002 and 2004, and the regional championship each year from 1995 to 1998 and in 2001 and 2002. He received Region 8-AA Coach of the Year honors five times and Associated Press Coach of the Year honors six times. In ten years at Briarcrest, Freeze was 94–30 as head coach (.785 winning percentage) and 126–37 overall.{{cite web |url=http://www.briarcrest.com/page.aspx?pid=821 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=September 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101213161936/http://briarcrest.com/page.aspx?pid=821 |archivedate=December 13, 2010}} Freeze was depicted in [[The Blind Side: Evolution of a Game|the book]] and motion picture ''[[The Blind Side (film)|The Blind Side]]'', about one of his former players, current free agent offensive tackle [[Michael Oher]].[http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/40483873/ns/sports-college_football/ Oher's HS Coach Gets Top Job at Arkansas State], NBC Sports, December 2, 2010. While at Briarcrest Christian School, Freeze also coached the girls basketball team from 1992 to 2004, and actually had more success in this role, with an overall record of 305–63 (.829 winning percentage), seven straight championship appearances, and four championships.{{cite web|url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2014/10/22/sports/ncaafootball/hugh-freeze-coach-at-ole-miss-follows-an-unlikely-blueprint.html|title=Hugh Freeze, Coach at Ole Miss, Follows an Unlikely Blueprint|accessdate=August 25, 2018}} Following his dismissal from [[Ole Miss]], some former students alleged that Freeze had engaged in inappropriate conduct with female students while at Briarcrest.{{cite news|last1=Heim|first1=Mark|title=Hugh Freeze stories emerge from former female students at Briarcrest Christian|url=https://www.al.com/sports/index.ssf/2017/07/hugh_freeze_stories_emerge_fro.html|work=AL.com|date=July 31, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Peter|first1=Josh|title=Who is Hugh Freeze? Conflicting views of former Ole Miss coach emerge |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ncaaf/2017/07/29/who-hugh-freeze-conflicting-views-former-ole-miss-coach-emerge/522705001/ |work=USA Today|date=July 29, 2017}} Freeze has denied the allegation and the school has stated it is unaware of any sexual improprieties involving Freeze during his tenure at the school. ===Ole Miss=== In 2005, the [[University of Mississippi]] hired Freeze as an assistant athletic director for football external affairs. The following season, he became the [[tight ends coach]] and [[recruiting coordinator]], positions he held through 2007. After [[2007 Ole Miss Rebels football team|that season]], he replaced head coach [[Ed Orgeron]] on an interim basis before the hiring of [[Houston Nutt]]. Freeze interviewed for the offensive coordinator position with Nutt,{{cite web |url=http://www.wtok.com/sports/headlines/13665882.html |title=Nutt Has Long List for New OC |date=January 9, 2008 |work=WTOK.com |accessdate=December 4, 2013}} a position that eventually went to [[Kent Austin]]. ===Lambuth=== In January 2008, [[Lambuth University]], a member of the [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics]] (NAIA), named Freeze its head coach.[http://www.lambutheagles.com/article/252.php Hugh Freeze Named Lambuth University Head Football Coach], Lambuth University, January 19, 2008. In 2008, he led Lambuth to an 8–4 record and a first round loss in the NAIA playoffs, marking their first appearance in the playoffs since 2004 under then head coach Vic Wallace. He was considered for the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga's head coaching position following the 2008 season, but remained at Lambuth University for another season and compiled a 20–5 overall record, and defeating opponents 41–17 on average. In 2009, he led the Eagles to their best regular season record in school history with an unblemished 11–0 mark. Lambuth advanced to the second round of the NAIA playoffs for first time in 11 years—having won one game before suffering elimination to finish 12–1 as the sixth-ranked team in the NAIA. ===Arkansas State=== In 2010, he joined the staff at [[Arkansas State Red Wolves football|Arkansas State]] as offensive coordinator after a brief stint as offensive coordinator at [[San Jose State University]] under [[Mike MacIntyre]]. The Red Wolves finished with a 4–8 record, but their offensive rankings jumped from 95th in total offense and 90th in scoring offense in the [[NCAA]] [[Division I FBS]] to 43rd and 46th, respectively. The Red Wolves' offense broke nine school records including total plays (856), first downs (262), pass attempts (438), pass completions (266), completion percentage (.607), passing yards (3,057), passing yards per game (254.8), and passing touchdowns (23). The Red Wolves' offense averaged 403.4 yards per game, eclipsing over 300 yards all 12 times it took the field for the first time in the history of the program. A-State posted at least 400 yards of total offense in seven games during the 2010 campaign, the most ever as an NCAA FBS member, all in his first year as offensive coordinator. After [[2010 Arkansas State Red Wolves football team|the season]], Freeze was promoted to replace head coach [[Steve Roberts (American football)|Steve Roberts]].[http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=5875374&campaign=rss&source=NCFHeadlines Hugh Freeze hired at Arkansas St.], ESPN, December 2, 2010. In 2011, his only season as head coach at Arkansas State, he led the Red Wolves to a 10–2 record and their first Sun Belt Conference title since 2005. The Red Wolves' offense averaged 447.8 ypg (28th nationally, 1st in Sun Belt Conference) including 293.6 ypg passing and 154.2 ypg rushing.{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/schools/arkansas-state/2011.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=September 26, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109125126/http://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/schools/arkansas-state/2011.html |archivedate=November 9, 2012}} Freeze left Arkansas State before the Arkansas State's appearance in the [[GoDaddy.com Bowl]] following the season. ===Ole Miss=== On December 5, 2011, Freeze was announced as the 37th head coach of the University of Mississippi. During the press conference to introduce Freeze as the head coach, he stated that he wanted to "retire at Ole Miss." He was signed to a four-year contract with an annual salary of $1.5 million plus incentives up to $2.5 million.{{cite news |title=Hugh Freeze is Rebels' new coach |url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/7319777/hugh-freeze-mississippi-rebels-emotional-accepting-coaching-job |agency=Associated Press |publisher=ESPN.com |date=December 5, 2011 |accessdate=December 5, 2011}} In his first season at Ole Miss, Freeze led the Rebels to a 6–6 record in the regular season, making Ole Miss bowl eligible for the first time since 2009 with a 41–24 victory over Mississippi State in the [[Egg Bowl]]. His Rebels accepted a bid to play in the BBVA Compass Bowl in Birmingham, Alabama, on January 5, 2013. They beat the University of Pittsburgh 38–17 to finish 7–6. Freeze received national attention on [[National Signing Day]] 2013 as Ole Miss brought in the fifth ranked recruiting class in the country.{{cite web |url=http://insider.espn.go.com/college-sports/football/recruiting/classrankings?class=2013 |title=2013 Football Class Rankings |work=ESPN.com |accessdate=December 4, 2013}} Freeze won the 2014 Grant Teaff Coach of the Year award by the Fellowship of Christian Athletes.{{cite web |url=http://www.fca.org/2014/01/13/hugh-freeze-named-grant-teaff-coach-of-the-year/ |title=Hugh Freeze named coach of the year by Fellowship of Christian Athletes |work=FCA.org |accessdate=January 13, 2014}} During Freeze's third season at Ole Miss, he led the Rebels to a 7–0 start, the program's best start since the [[Johnny Vaught]] era. By October, they had risen as high as third in the nation, their highest ranking at that late stage in the season in almost half a century. They ultimately finished 9–3, only the third time since Vaught's tenure that Ole Miss has won that many games in the regular season. That netted them an appearance in the [[2014 Peach Bowl]]–their first major bowl appearance since the [[1970 Sugar Bowl]], and easily the biggest bowl they had attended since Vaught's tenure. On September 19, 2015, Freeze's Rebels beat Alabama, 43–37, in [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama]], making Freeze only the third head coach, along with [[Les Miles]] and [[Steve Spurrier]], to defeat a [[Nick Saban]]-coached team in back-to-back years (Michigan's Lloyd Carr beat Saban's Michigan State Spartans in three consecutive years, '96–'98). The victory catapulted the Rebels to #3 in the AP rankings. They went on to tally their second straight nine-win season, and garnered a berth in the [[2016 Sugar Bowl]], where they won 48–20 over [[Oklahoma State Cowboys football|Oklahoma State]]. They finished ninth in the AP Poll and 10th in the Coaches' Poll—their first top-10 finishes in a final poll since 1969. In January 2016, the NCAA charged Ole Miss with numerous recruiting violations. An investigation turned up evidence that Ole Miss employees and boosters arranged numerous "impermissible benefits" for players, such as car loans and cash. At least one recruit was suspected of getting help on his college entrance exam.{{cite news|url=https://www.sbnation.com/college-football/2017/2/22/14703296/ole-miss-ncaa-allegations-list-2017|title=The updated list of 21 NCAA allegations against Ole Miss football|author=Morgan Moriarty|publisher=[[SB Nation]] |date= February 22, 2017}} The investigation reopened soon after star offensive tackle [[Laremy Tunsil]] admitted taking money from one of Freeze's assistants.{{cite news |title=Laremy Tunsil says he took money from coach at Ole Miss |work=ESPN |date=April 28, 2016 |url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/15424437/2016-nfl-draft-laremy-tunsil-admits-taking-cash-ole-miss-rebels-coach}} In February 2017—three months after suffering its first losing season since the year Freeze arrived—Ole Miss withdrew from bowl consideration for the upcoming season. The move came on the same day that the NCAA sent an updated notice of allegations charging the Rebels with eight additional violations. Most seriously, it accused Freeze of not monitoring his assistants, and also accused Ole Miss of not properly controlling the program. On July 13, 2017, Freeze's predecessor, [[Houston Nutt]], sued Ole Miss for defamation, contending that Freeze and school officials falsely blamed him for the violations. As part of discovery for the lawsuit, Nutt's attorneys filed a [[Freedom of Information Act]] request for calls Freeze made on his university-issued cell phone during January 2016. Nutt's attorneys contended that Freeze and others at Ole Miss leaked information to the press as part of an effort to smear their client.http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/sns-bc-fbc--mississippi-freezes-downfall-20170721-story.html While reviewing those records, Nutt's attorneys discovered a call to a number associated with a female [[escort service]], and alerted Ole Miss officials about it. Freeze claimed it was a misdialed number.{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ncaaf/sec/2017/07/20/ole-miss-coach-hugh-freeze-called-number-tied-escort-service/498056001/|title=Ole Miss football coach Hugh Freeze made call to number tied to escort service|accessdate=August 25, 2018}} School officials investigated, and discovered what they later described as "a concerning pattern" of similar calls dating back to shortly after he arrived in Oxford. On July 20, chancellor [[Jeff Vitter]] and athletic director [[Ross Bjork]] gave Freeze an ultimatum: resign or be fired for violating the [[morals clause]] of his contract. Freeze opted to resign; offensive coordinator [[Matt Luke (American football)|Matt Luke]] was named interim coach.{{Cite news |url=http://www.espn.com/college-football/story/_/id/20117453/hugh-freeze-ole-miss-rebels-resigns-escort-service-calls-cited |title=Ole Miss coach Hugh Freeze resigns; escort-service calls cited |last=Schlabach |first=Mark |date=July 20, 2017 |work=[[ESPN.com]] |author-link=Mark Schlabach}} ===Arizona Hotshots (AAF)=== On October 11, 2018, Freeze was named as the Offensive Coordinator for the [[Arizona Hotshots]] of the [[Alliance of American Football]]. ==Personal life== Freeze and his wife Jill have three daughters; Ragan, Jordan and Madison.{{cite web |url=https://mschristianliving.com/2016/covers/jill-freeze-life-calling/|title=Jill Freeze—Her Life and Calling – Mississippi Christian Living|date=May 1, 2016|accessdate=August 25, 2018}} Freeze is a [[born again]] [[Christian]] and has been outspoken about his faith throughout his coaching career.{{cite web|url=http://www.bpnews.net/50253/hugh-and-jill-freeze-speak-of-gods-grace-at-liberty-u|title=Hugh & Jill Freeze speak of God's grace at Liberty U.|first=Art|last=Toalston |website=www.bpnews.net |accessdate=August 25, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.oxfordeagle.com/2017/07/26/hugh-freeze-asks-for-prayer-looking-to-get-life-back-together-mississippi-pastor/|title=Hugh Freeze asks for prayer, looking to get life back together: Mississippi pastor |date=July 26, 2017|accessdate=August 25, 2018}} He and his family attend [[Pinelake Church]] in Oxford.{{cite web |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2017/08/04/public-sin-how-evangelical-christians-responding/520251001/|title=Hugh Freeze, sin and the scandal's impact on evangelical Christians|accessdate=August 25, 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://www.gospelherald.com/articles/71180/20170727/pastors-rally-around-hugh-freeze-former-ole-miss-coach-god.htm|title=Pastors Rally Around Hugh Freeze; Former Ole Miss Coach Says 'God is Good Even in Difficult Times'|first=The Gospel|last=Herald|date=July 27, 2017|accessdate=August 25, 2018}} ==Head coaching record== {{CFB Yearly Record Start | type = coach | team = | conf = | bowl = | poll = both}} {{CFB Yearly Record Subhead | name = [[Lambuth Eagles football|Lambuth Eagles]] | conf = [[Mid-South Conference]] | startyear = 2008 | Murray Abraham]] }} | narrator = [[Courtney B. Vance]] | music = [[Alexandre Desplat]] | cinematography = Tristan Oliver | editing = {{Plainlist| * Ralph Foster * Edward Bursch }} | studio = {{Plain list| * [[Studio Babelsberg]] * Indian Paintbrush * American Empirical Pictures }} | distributor = [[Fox Searchlight Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2018|2|15|[[68th Berlin International Film Festival|Berlinale]]|2018|3|23|United States|2018|5|10|Germany}} | runtime = 97 minutes{{cite web |url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/isle-dogs-2018|title=''Isle of Dogs'' (PG) |publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]] |date=March 20, 2018 |accessdate=June 1, 2018}} | country = {{Plainlist| * United States * Germany{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/reviews/isle-of-dogs-review-1202700010/|last=Lodge|first=Guy|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|title=Film Review: 'Isle of Dogs'|date=February 15, 2018|accessdate=March 23, 2018 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}}{{cite news|url=http://film.britishcouncil.org/isle-of-dogs1/|title=British Council Film: Isle of Dogs|accessdate=March 23, 2018 |publisher=[[British Council]]|work=British Film Directory}}{{cite news|url=https://www.screendaily.com/reviews/isle-of-dogs-berlin-review/5126636.article|title='Isle Of Dogs': Berlin Review|date=February 16, 2018|accessdate=March 23, 2018 |work=Screen Daily|publisher=[[Screen International]]}} }} | language = English
Japanese | budget = | gross = $64.2 million{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=isleofdogs.htm |title=''Isle of Dogs'' (2018)|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=August 26, 2018}} }} {{nihongo|'''''Isle of Dogs'''''|犬ヶ島|Inugashima|lead=yes}} is a 2018 [[Stop motion|stop-motion-animated]] [[science-fiction]] [[comedy-drama]] film written, produced and directed by [[Wes Anderson]]. Set in a [[dystopia]]n near-future [[Japan]], the story follows a young boy searching for his dog after the species is banished to an island following the outbreak of a [[canine flu]]. The film's ensemble voice cast includes [[Bryan Cranston]], [[Edward Norton]], [[Bill Murray]], [[Jeff Goldblum]], [[Bob Balaban]], [[Greta Gerwig]], [[Frances McDormand]], [[Courtney B. Vance]], [[Fisher Stevens]], [[Harvey Keitel]], [[Liev Schreiber]], [[Scarlett Johansson]], [[Tilda Swinton]], [[F. Murray Abraham]], [[Frank Wood (actor)|Frank Wood]], [[Kunichi Nomura]], and [[Yoko Ono]]. A US–German co-production, ''Isle of Dogs'' was produced by [[Steven M. Rales|Indian Paintbrush]] and Anderson's own production company, American Empirical Pictures, in association with [[Babelsberg Studio|Studio Babelsberg]]. The film opened the [[68th Berlin International Film Festival]], where Anderson was awarded the [[Silver Bear for Best Director]]. It was given a limited release in the United States on March 23, 2018, by [[Fox Searchlight Pictures]], and went on wide release on April 13. It has grossed over $64 million worldwide, and received praise for its animation, story, and [[deadpan]] humor. A [[manga]] adaptation of the film by [[Minetarō Mochizuki]] was published in 2018, beginning with the May 24 issue of ''[[Weekly Morning]]''.{{cite web|url=https://natalie.mu/comic/news/283507|title=望月ミネタロウ「犬ヶ島」コミカライズがモーニングで始動、表紙は大友克洋|trans-title=Minetarō Mochizuki "Inugashima" comicalize starting in ''Morning'', cover is Katsuhiro Ōtomo|date=May 24, 2018|website=[[Natalie (website)|Natalie]]|access-date=July 20, 2018}}{{cite news |title=''Dragon Head''{{'}}s Minetarō Mochizuki draws ''Isle of Dogs'' manga |author=Rafael Antonio Pineda |url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2018-04-20/dragon-head-minetaro-mochizuki-draws-isle-of-dogs-manga/.130621 |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=April 20, 2018 |accessdate=July 21, 2018}} ==Plot== In a dystopian near-future Japan, an influenza virus spreads throughout the canine population, with a risk of crossing to humans. The 6-term authoritarian mayor of Megasaki City, Kenji Kobayashi, signs a decree banishing all dogs to Trash Island, despite a scientist named Professor Watanabe insisting he is close to finding a cure for the [[Canine influenza|dog flu]]. The first to be exiled is Spots, who belonged to Atari Kobayashi, the orphaned nephew and [[Ward (law)|ward]] of the mayor. Six months later, Atari steals a plane and flies to Trash Island to search for Spots. After crash-landing, Atari is rescued by a pack of dogs led by a seemingly black dog named Chief, who is a former stray. The pack decides to help Atari locate Spots, although Chief refuses to join because of his inability to fraternize with humans. Together, they fend off a rescue team accompanied by a robot dog that Kobayashi sent to retrieve Atari. Kobayashi claims Atari was kidnapped by the dogs and vows to kill them as punishment. At the insistence of a female [[Purebred|purebreed]] named Nutmeg, Chief reluctantly decides to accompany the group on their search. They seek advice from two sage dogs, Jupiter and Oracle, who warn them of the existence of an isolated tribe of dogs rumored to be [[Cannibalism|cannibals]]. Meanwhile, Professor Watanabe finds a cure and shows the results to Kobayashi, who still refuses to lift the dog ban. The professor is put on house arrest for criticizing Kobayashi and is then killed by poisoned [[wasabi]] in sushi. An American [[Student exchange program|exchange student]], Tracy Walker, suspects a conspiracy and begins to investigate. During the journey, Chief and Atari are separated from the others. Atari gives Chief a bath, which reveals that his coat is actually white. Noticing the similarity between Chief and Spots, Atari realizes they must be of the same extremely rare breed. Chief remembers being part of a litter of which all but one died. He bonds with Atari as they continue their journey. They rejoin the group, but are ambushed by Kobayashi's men. Spots arrives with the cannibal tribe, and they fend off the assailants together, causing Kobayashi to declare Atari to be dead. Spots confirms that Chief is his brother, and reveals that he was rescued by the tribe, who were not actually cannibals, became their leader, and mated with a female dog, Peppermint. Because of these circumstances, he asks to transfer his protection duties for Atari to Chief, which is granted. An owl brings word that Kobayashi plans to order the extermination of all dogs on Trash Island and replace them with the robot dogs. Atari and the dogs prepare their journey to the mainland. Tracy confronts Watanabe's former colleague Yoko Ono, who confirms Tracy's suspicions and gives her the last remaining vial of the cure. At his re-election ceremony, Kobayashi prepares to give the order, but Tracy presents her evidence of his corruption. However, Kobayashi dismisses Tracy's evidence and orders her expulsion from Japan and deportation back to the United States. Chief, Atari and the dogs soon arrive, and confirm the cure works. Atari then presents a [[haiku]], dedicated to Kobayashi, that signifies the sympathy that previously existed between dogs and humans. Kobayashi has a change of heart and revokes the decree, but his right-hand man, Major Domo, insists on triggering the extermination. A fight ensues with Kobayashi and Domo in which the "execute" button is pressed, but the poison backfires on the captors thanks to the help of a hacker from Tracy's high school. During the fight, Atari and Spots are gravely injured by the robot dog. Atari's remaining kidney fails, but Kobayashi, admitting his mistakes, donates one of his own to save him. By law, mayorship of the city falls to Atari, and he decrees that dogs are allowed to reintegrate into society. Kobayashi along with Major Domo and their political allies are jailed for their corruption. Tracy and Atari become a couple, and Chief reunites with Nutmeg and takes up the role of bodyguard for Atari. Spots, who had been presumed dead, recovers and secretly raises his litter with Peppermint under the Kobayashi [[manor]]. ==Cast== {{Cast listing| * [[Bryan Cranston]] as Chief{{cite web | title=Isle of Dogs (2018) | url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/5a8613e53589c | publisher=[[British Film Institute]] | accessdate=March 15, 2018}} * Koyu Rankin as Atari Kobayashi * [[Edward Norton]] as Rex * [[Bob Balaban]] as King * [[Bill Murray]] as Boss * [[Jeff Goldblum]] as Duke * [[Kunichi Nomura]] as Mayor Kenji Kobayashi * [[Akira Takayama]] as Major Domo * [[Greta Gerwig]] as Tracy Walker * [[Frances McDormand]] as Interpreter Nelson * Akira Ito as Professor Watanabe * [[Scarlett Johansson]] as Nutmeg * [[Harvey Keitel]] as Gondo * [[F. Murray Abraham]] as Jupiter * [[Yoko Ono]] as Assistant Scientist Yoko Ono * [[Tilda Swinton]] as Oracle * [[Ken Watanabe]] as Head Surgeon * [[Mari Natsuki]] as Auntie * [[Fisher Stevens]] as Scrap * Nijiro Murakami as Editor Hiroshi * [[Liev Schreiber]] as Spots * [[Courtney B. Vance]] as the narrator{{cite web | title=Isle of Dogs | url=https://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/2018/02_programm_2018/02_Filmdatenblatt_2018_201819628.html#tab=filmStills | accessdate=February 23, 2018|publisher=[[Berlin International Film Festival]]|work=Annual Archives: 2018}} * [[Yojiro Noda]] as News Anchor{{cite web | title=Isle of Dogs official website | url=http://www.isleofdogsmovie.com/ | accessdate=March 21, 2018 |publisher=[[Fox Searchlight Pictures]]}} * [[Frank Wood (actor)|Frank Wood]] as Simul-Translate Machine * [[Roman Coppola]] as Igor * [[Anjelica Huston]] as Mute Poodle * [[Kara Hayward]] as Peppermint }} ==Production== ===Development=== [[File:Isle of Dogs - Press Conference 2.jpg|thumb|''Isle of Dogs'' press conference at the 68th Berlin International Film Festival, February 2018]] In October 2015, Anderson, who had previously directed the animated film ''[[Fantastic Mr. Fox (film)|Fantastic Mr. Fox]]'', announced he would be returning to the genre with "a film about dogs"{{cite web|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2015/10/12/wes-anderson-to-direct-stop-motion-animated-film-about-dogs|title=Wes Anderson to Direct Stop-Motion Animated Film About Dogs|date=October 12, 2015|last=Osborn|first=Alex|accessdate=March 23, 2018|work=[[IGN]] UK|publisher=[[Ziff Davis]]}} starring Edward Norton, Bryan Cranston and Bob Balaban.{{cite web|last1=Casey|first1=Dan|title=Exclusive: Jeff Goldblum, Bryan Cranston, and More to Star in Wes Anderson's Stop-Motion Animated Dog Movie |url=http://nerdist.com/wes-anderson-stop-motion-animated-movie-dogs-jeff-goldblum-bryan-cranston/|website=[[Nerdist Industries|Nerdist]]|date=October 12, 2015|accessdate=December 21, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Perez|first1=Rodrigo|title=Wes Anderson's Next Movie Is A Stop-Motion Animated Film About Dogs; May Also Do An Anthology Movie|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/wes-andersons-next-movie-is-a-stop-motion-animated-film-about-dogs-may-also-do-an-anthology-movie-20151009|website=[[IndieWire|The Playlist]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=October 9, 2015}} Anderson has said that he was inspired by seeing a road sign for the [[Isle of Dogs]] in England while ''Fantastic Mr. Fox'' was in development.{{cite web|url=http://adam-buxton.co.uk/podcasts/ep70-garth-jennings-wes-anderson|title=EP.70 - GARTH JENNINGS & WES ANDERSON|website=The Adam Buxton Podcast|first=Adam|last=Buxton|date=March 31, 2018|accessdate=July 20, 2018}} Anderson said that the film was strongly influenced by the films of [[Akira Kurosawa]], as well as the [[stop motion|stop-motion]] animated holiday specials made by [[Rankin/Bass Productions]].{{cite web | url = https://www.yahoo.com/movies/wes-anderson-isle-dogs-inspired-173402638.html | title = Wes Anderson's 'Isle of Dogs' is Inspired By Akira Kurosawa and Christmas Television Specials | first= Zach | last= Sharf | date = March 13, 2017 | accessdate = March 17, 2017 | work = [[IndieWire]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]}} ===Filming=== Production began in October 2016 at the [[3 Mills Studios]] in East London.{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/wes-anderson-new-movie-animated/|publisher=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex Media]]|title=Wes Anderson Confirms His Stop-Motion Animated Dog Movie Is In Production|website=[[Collider (website)|Collider]]|first=Chris|last=Cabin|date=October 27, 2016|accessdate=December 21, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://screencrush.com/wes-anderson-filming-new-project/|title=Wes Anderson Is Currently Filming His New Stop-Motion Animated Movie About Dogs|website=[[Screen Crush]]|publisher=[[Townsquare Media]]|first=Britt|last=Hayes|date=October 27, 2016|accessdate=October 27, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.3mills.com/isle-of-dogs/ |title=Isle of Dogs |publisher=[[3 Mills Studios]]|accessdate=April 6, 2018}} The animation department included a number of people who had worked on ''Fantastic Mr. Fox''.{{cite news |last1=James |first1=Nick |title=Where Beagles Dare |publisher=[[British Film Institute]] |work=[[Sight & Sound]] |date=April 2018 |url=https://www.bfi.org.uk/news-opinion/sight-sound-magazine/april-2018-issue |accessdate=July 20, 2018}} 20,000 faces and animatable 1,105 puppets were crafted by "12 sculptors working six days a week" for the film.Murphy, Jackson. [http://www.animationscoop.com/interview-with-isle-of-dogs-stop-mo-model-maker-andy-gent/ "INTERVIEW with 'Isle Of Dogs' Stop-Mo Model Maker Andy Gent."] ''Animation Scoop''. 29 October 2018. 29 October 2018. 2,000 more puppets were made for background characters. The detailed puppets of the main characters took an average of two to three months to create. ==Release== On December 23, 2016, [[Fox Searchlight Pictures]] acquired worldwide distribution rights to the film, with plans for a 2018 release.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/12/fox-searchlight-world-rights-isle-of-dogs-wes-anderson-1201874923/|title=Fox Searchlight Takes World Rights On Wes Anderson's 'Isle Of Dogs'|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|first=Nancy|last=Tartaglione|date=December 22, 2016|accessdate=December 22, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/fox-searchlight-takes-world-rights-to-wes-andersons-isle-of-dogs/5112447.article|title=Fox Searchlight takes world rights to Wes Anderson's 'Isle Of Dogs'|website=Screen Daily|publisher=[[Screen International]]|first=Tom|last=Grater|date=December 22, 2016|accessdate=December 22, 2016}} A trailer was released on September 21, 2017.{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dt__kig8PVU|date=September 21, 2017|title=ISLE OF DOGS {{!}} Official Trailer {{!}} FOX Searchlight |author=[[Fox Searchlight Pictures]] |publisher=[[YouTube]] |accessdate=April 19, 2018}} The film premiered as the opening film of the 68th Berlin International Film Festival on February 15, 2018, and had its North American premiere as the closing film of the [[South by Southwest|SXSW Film Festival]] in Austin, Texas, on March 17, 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/sxsw-wes-andersons-isle-dogs-close-fest-1082755|title=SXSW: Wes Anderson's 'Isle of Dogs' to Close Festival|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=March 18, 2018|last=Galuppo|first=Mia|date=February 7, 2018}} ''Isle of Dogs'' began a limited release in the U.S. on March 23, 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/wes-andersons-isle-dogs-gets-release-date-poster-photo/|title=Wes Anderson's 'Isle of Dogs' Gets Release Date, Poster (Photo)|website=[[TheWrap]]|first=Nigel M.|last=Smith|date=April 25, 2017|accessdate=April 25, 2017}} It was released nationwide in the United States on April 13, 2018.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/box-office/wes-andersons-isle-of-dogs-strong-indie-box-office-1202735904/|title=Wes Anderson’s ‘Isle of Dogs’ Prances to Top Screen Average of 2018|first=Rebecca |last=Rubin|date=March 25, 2018|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|access-date=March 31, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/03/isle-of-dogs-wes-anderson-stanley-tucci-final-portrait-specialty-box-office-preview-1202352241/|title=Wes Anderson Returns With 'Isle Of Dogs'; Stanley Tucci Back With 'Final Portrait' – Specialty B.O. Preview|first=Brian|last=Brooks|date=March 23, 2018|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|accessdate=March 24, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://animatedviews.com/2018/update-isle-of-dogs-is-getting-a-wide-release-in-the-coming-weeks/|title=UPDATE: Isle of Dogs is getting a wide release in the coming weeks|website=Animated Views|accessdate=March 24, 2018|author=James|date=March 20, 2018}} ''Isle of Dogs'' was released on digital on June 26, 2018, and on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray]] on July 17, 2018.{{cite web |url=https://www.dvdsreleasedates.com/movies/8759/isle-of-dogs |title=Isle of Dogs (2018) |work=DVDs Release Dates |accessdate=August 21, 2018}} ==Reception== ===Box office=== {{As of|2018|8|26|df=US|alt=''Isle of Dogs'' has grossed $32 million in the United States and Canada, and $32.1 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $64.1 million.}} In its first weekend of limited release, the film made $1.57 million from 27 theaters (an average of $58,148 per venue). It was the best per-theater average of 2018 until it was overtaken by ''[[Eighth Grade (film)|Eighth Grade]]'' in July.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/box-office/eighth-grade-top-screen-average-2018-indie-box-office-1202873675/|title=‘Eighth Grade’ Rules Indie Box Office With Top Screen Average of 2018|last=Rubin|first=Rebecca|date=July 15, 2018|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|access-date=July 17, 2018}} Sixty percent of its audience was under the age of 30.{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2018/03/pacific-rim-uprising-black-panther-weekend-box-office-1202352184/|title=Does 'Pacific Rim: Uprising' Break Even At The Global B.O.?; 'Black Panther' Sets Marvel Record – Sunday Postmortem|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=March 25, 2018 |first=Anthony |last=D'Alessandro|accessdate=March 25, 2018}} In its second weekend the film made $2.8 million from 165 theaters (an increase of 74 percent), finishing 11th.{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2018/03/ready-player-one-steven-spielberg-opening-weekend-box-office-1202318581/|title=How Warner Bros. Sold 'Ready Player One' On The Spielberg Spirit & Beat Tracking With $53M+ 4-Day – Sunday Postmortem|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=April 1, 2018 |first1=Anthony |last1=D'Alessandro|accessdate=April 2, 2018}} The film entered the top 10 in its third weekend, making $4.6 million from 554 theaters.{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2018/04/a-quiet-place-blockers-ready-player-one-weekend-box-office-1202359716/|title='A Quiet Place' Screams To $50M+ Opening; 'Blockers' Breaks Through To $21M+ – Early Sunday Update|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=April 8, 2018 |first1=Anthony |last1=D'Alessandro|accessdate=April 8, 2018}} The film expanded to 1,939 theaters the following week and made $5 million, finishing 7th at the box office.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/04/dwayne-johnson-rampage-box-office-weekend-a-quiet-place-1202363694/|title=The Rock Rebounds: 'Rampage' Shushes 'A Quiet Place' With $34M+ No. 1 Opening|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=April 15, 2018|first1=Anthony|last1=D'Alessandro|accessdate=April 15, 2018}} ===Critical response=== On review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film holds an approval rating of 89% based on 295 reviews, and an average rating of 8/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "The beautifully stop-motion animated ''Isle of Dogs'' finds Wes Anderson at his detail-oriented best while telling one of the director's most winsomely charming stories."{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/isle_of_dogs_2018 |title=Isle of Dogs (2018) |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango Media]] |accessdate=August 27, 2018}} On [[Metacritic]], which assigns normalized ratings to reviews, the film has a weighted average score of 82 out of 100, based on 55 critics, indicating "universal acclaim."{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/isle-of-dogs|title=Isle of Dogs Reviews|work=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=April 11, 2018}} Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "A" on an A+ to F scale, while [[PostTrak]] reported filmgoers gave it an overall positive score of 88 percent.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/04/dwayne-johnson-rampage-box-office-weekend-a-quiet-place-1202363694/|title=Dwayne Johnson Ape Movie 'Rampage' Grabs $2.4M In Thursday Previews|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=April 13, 2018|first1=Anthony|last1=D'Alessandro|accessdate=April 13, 2018}} Richard Roeper of the ''Chicago Sun-Times'' gave the film 3.5 out of 4 stars, praising it for taking risks, and saying: "It's smart and different and sometimes deliberately odd and really funny—rarely in a laugh-out-loud way, more in a smile-and-nod-I-get-the-joke kind of way."{{cite news |last=Roeper |first=Richard |authorlink=Richard Roeper |date=March 27, 2018 |title='Isle of Dogs': Wes Anderson finds beauty in exiled pups, sick but soulful|url=https://chicago.suntimes.com/entertainment/isle-of-dogs-wes-anderson-finds-beauty-in-exiled-pups-sick-but-soulful/|website=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |accessdate=April 1, 2018}} ''[[Exclaim!]]'' gave the film 7 out of 10, saying it "has all the hallmarks of another Wes Anderson classic."{{cite web|url=https://exclaim.ca/film/article/isle_of_dogs-directed_by_wes_andreson|last=Clapp|first=Tim|date=March 29, 2018|title=Isle of Dogs|work=[[Exclaim!]]|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} ===Portrayal of Japanese culture=== Some critics have argued that the film is an example of racial stereotyping and [[cultural appropriation]], and that one of its characters aligns with the trope of the "[[White savior narrative in film|white savior]]".{{cite web | last=Clift | first=Tom | title=Wes Anderson's 'Isle Of Dogs' Has Been Accused Of Cultural Appropriation | url=http://junkee.com/isle-of-dogs-cultural-appropriation/152070 | website=[[Junkee]] | publisher=[[Junkee Media]] | date=March 25, 2018 | accessdate=March 28, 2018}} The Japanese characters speak unsubtitled [[Japanese language|Japanese]], with their dialogue instead being translated by an interpreter or a machine. Justin Chang of the ''Los Angeles Times'' wrote "It's in the director's handling of the story's human factor that his sensitivity falters, and the weakness for racial stereotyping that has sometimes marred his work comes to the fore ... Much of the Japanese dialogue has been pared down to simple statements that non-speakers can figure out based on context and facial expressions". Angie Han, writing in ''[[Mashable]]'', calls the American exchange student character Tracy a "classic example of the 'white savior' archetype—the well-meaning white hero who arrives in a foreign land and saves its people from themselves". While this critique has created some furore on the film's release, Chang has said that his review had been taken out of context and turned into a "battle cry" on Twitter, adding, "I wasn't offended; nor was I looking to be offended".{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/films/2018/03/22/wes-andersons-isle-dogs-sparks-controversy-depiction-japan/ | title=Wes Anderson's Isle of Dogs sparks controversy over depiction of Japan | work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | author=Telegraph Reporters | publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]] | date=March 22, 2018 | accessdate=March 28, 2018}} Another Japanese-American perspective was provided by Emily Yoshida, writing in ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine, that these concerns had been "seen before in debates about Asian culture as reflected by Western culture—perspectives can vary wildly between Asian-Americans and immigrated Asians, and what feels like tribute to some feels like opportunism to others".{{cite web | last=Yoshida | first=Emily | title=What It's Like to Watch Isle of Dogs As a Japanese Speaker | url=http://www.vulture.com/2018/03/what-its-like-to-watch-isle-of-dogs-as-a-japanese-speaker.html| website=Vulture | publisher=[[New York (magazine)|New York Media]] | date=March 29, 2018 | accessdate=April 25, 2018}} Writing for BuzzFeed, Alison Willmore found "no overt malicious intent to ''Isle of Dogs''{{'}} [[cultural tourism]], but it's marked by a hodgepodge of references that an American like Anderson might cough up if pressed to [[Free association (psychology)|free associate]] about Japan—[[taiko]] drummers, [[anime]], [[Hokusai]], [[sumo]], [[kabuki]], [[haiku]], [[cherry blossom]]s, and a mushroom cloud (!). ... This all has more to do with the ... insides of Anderson's brain than it does any actual place. It's Japan purely as an aesthetic—and another piece of art that treats the East not as a living, breathing half of the planet but as a mirror for the Western imagination".{{Cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/alisonwillmore/isle-of-dogs-jared-leto-orientalism|title=Orientalism Is Alive And Well In American Cinema|last=Willmore|first=Alison|date=April 5, 2018|work=BuzzFeed News|publisher=[[BuzzFeed]]|access-date=April 5, 2018}} She continued, "in the wake of ''Isle of Dogs''{{'}} opening weekend, there were multiple headlines wondering whether the film was an act of appropriation or homage. But the question is rhetorical—the two aren't mutually exclusive, and the former is not automatically off the table just because the creator's intent was the latter". Conversely, Moeko Fujii wrote a favorable review for ''[[The New Yorker]]'', complimenting the film's depiction of the Japanese and their culture, as well as pointing out that language is the key theme of the movie. Fujii wrote,
Anderson's decision not to subtitle the Japanese speakers struck me as a carefully considered artistic choice. ''Isle of Dogs'' is profoundly interested in the humor and fallibility of translation ... This is the beating heart of the film: there is no such thing as "true" translation. Everything is interpreted. Translation is malleable and implicated, always, by systems of power ... [the film] shows the seams of translation, and demarcates a space that is accessible—and funny—only to Japanese viewers.{{cite web | last=Fujii | first=Moeko | title=What Wes Anderson's "Isle Of Dogs" Gets Right About Japan | url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/cultural-comment/what-isle-of-dogs-gets-right-about-japan | website=[[The New Yorker]] | publisher=[[Condé Nast]] | date=April 13, 2018 | accessdate=April 13, 2018}}
Fujii also deconstructed the criticisms of the character of Tracy Walker being a "white savior," and how this relates to the film's language theme, writing,
At a climactic moment, the movie rejects the notion of universal legibility, placing the onus of interpretation solely upon the American audience ... This is a sly subversion, in which the Japanese evince an agency independent of foreign validation. Indeed, to say that the scene dehumanizes the Japanese is to assume the primacy of an English-speaking audience. Such logic replicates the very tyranny of language that ''Isle of Dogs'' attempts to erode.
==Soundtrack== {{Anchor|Music}} {{Infobox album | name = Isle of Dogs: Original Soundtrack | type = soundtrack | artist = [[Alexandre Desplat]] | cover = | alt = | released = {{startdate|2018|3|23}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = [[Associated Independent Recording|Air Studios]], London, UK{{cite web|title=Alexandre Desplat – Isle Of Dogs (Original Soundtrack)|url=https://www.discogs.com/Alexandre-Desplat-Isle-Of-Dogs-Original-Soundtrack/release/11788433|website=[[Discogs]]|accessdate=April 13, 2018}} | genre = Soundtrack | length = | label = [[ABKCO Records|ABKCO]] 18771849322 | producer = {{hlist|[[Wes Anderson]]|[[Randall Poster]]}} | chronology = Wes Anderson film soundtrack | prev_title = [[The Grand Budapest Hotel#Soundtrack|The Grand Budapest Hotel]] | prev_year = 2014 | next_title = | next_year = }} {{Album ratings | rev1 = ''Backseat Mafia'' | rev1score = 7.5/10{{cite web|url=http://www.backseatmafia.com/album-review-isle-of-dogs-original-soundtrack/|title=Album Review: Isle of Dogs – Original Soundtrack|work=Backseat Mafia|last=Bryan|first=Jon|date=March 27, 2018|accessdate=April 13, 2018}} | rev2 = ''[[Drowned in Sound]]'' | rev2score = 7/10{{cite web|url=http://drownedinsound.com/releases/20269/reviews/4151727|title=Album Review: Various - Isle Of Dogs (Original Soundtrack)|work=[[Drowned in Sound]]|last=Goggins|first=Joe|date=April 11, 2018|accessdate=April 13, 2018}} | rev3 = ''[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]'' | rev3score = 7.3/10{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/various-artists-isle-of-dogs-original-soundtrack/|title=Various Artists: Isle of Dogs (Original Soundtrack) Album Review|work=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|last=Marsh|first=Calum|date=March 28, 2018|accessdate=April 13, 2018}} |noprose=yes }} The film's score was composed by [[Alexandre Desplat]], who had previously worked with Anderson on ''[[Fantastic Mr. Fox (film)|Fantastic Mr. Fox]]'', ''[[Moonrise Kingdom]],'' and ''[[The Grand Budapest Hotel]]''. The soundtrack also features various original and selected songs from a variety of musicians, mainly from Japan. Some songs had origins in classic Japanese cinema such as the [[Akira Kurosawa]] films ''[[Drunken Angel]]'' (1948) and ''[[Seven Samurai]]'' (1954). The soundtrack comprises 22 tracks in total, 15 of which were composed by Desplat.{{cite {{Orphan|date=June 2016}} '''Lifewide education''' is an educational concept that recognizes that [[learning]] occurs in multiple contexts within a learner's life: school, home, work, etc. It is the means by which an educational institution encourages, supports and recognizes students' lifewide learning. It is a concept that is compared and contrasted to [[life-long learning|lifelong education]], recognizing that not only does learning occur continually throughout one's life, it occurs broadly across every situation in one's life. The modern concept of lifewide learning first emerged in a report prepared by the [[National Agency for Education (Sweden)|Swedish National Agency for Education]] which stated:
''The lifelong dimension represents what the individual learns throughout the whole life-span. Knowledge rapidly becomes obsolete and it is necessary for the individual to update knowledge and competence in a continuous process of learning. Education cannot be limited to the time spent in school, the individual must have a real opportunity to learn throughout life. The lifelong dimension is non-problematic, what is essential is that the individual learns throughout life. The ''lifewide dimension'' refers to the fact that learning takes place in a variety of different environments and situations, and is not only confined to the formal educational system. ''Lifewide learning'' covers formal, non-formal and informal learning''. {{cite report |url=http://www.skolverket.se/2.3894/publicerat/publikationer?_xurl_=http%3A%2F%2Fwww4.skolverket.se%3A8080%2Fwtpub%2Fws%2Fskolbok%2Fwpubext%2Ftrycksak%2FRecord%3Bjsessionid%3D49E9CD537D5C2F524E40306FDD0E4B6E%3Fm%3D20%26w%3DNATIVE%2528%2527title%2B%253D%2B%2527%2527L%2527%2527*%2527%2529 |title=Lifelong Learning and Lifewide Learning |publisher=[[National Agency for Education (Sweden)|Skolverket]] |year=2000 |page=7 }}
The idea quickly spread through the policy community and became incorporated into the thinking of economists concerned with measuring value in lifelong learning. A presentation entitled "Measuring the Impact of the New Economy in Education Sector Outputs" dated 2002 on the UK Government Statistics Office website, makes reference to '''measuring lifewide learning'''.{{citation needed|date=February 2012}} Richard Desjardins utilised the idea of lifewide learning in his conceptual framework for the economic evaluation of lifelong learning. {{cite report |first1=Tom|last1=Schuller |first2=Richard|last2=Desjardins |title=Understanding the Social Outcomes of Learning |publisher=[[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]] |year=2007 |url=http://ul.fcpe.rueil.free.fr/IMG/pdf/9607061E.pdf }} :''Learning does not occur just in school – it is both ''lifewide'' (i.e. it occurs in multiple contexts, such as work, at home and in our social lives) and ''lifelong'' (from cradle to grave). These different types of learning affect each other in a wide variety of ways. Their impact in terms of the outcomes of learning is equally complex – whether it is in the economic and social spheres, the individual and collective, the monetary and the non-monetary. Further complicating the picture are substantial gaps in our knowledge base on a number of issues, including the following: :*''The cumulative and interactive impacts of lifewide and lifelong learning. :*''The potential impacts of informal learning, later interventions in adulthood or even different types of formal education :*''And the impacts of different curricula (general, academic, vocational) and impacts of different learning at different stages.''{{rp|10}} More recently an EU Foresight Report, "The Future of Learning: Preparing for Change", incorporated the lifewide concept into its central learning paradigm. {{cite report |title=The Future of Learning: Preparing for Change |first1=Christine|last1=Redecker |first2=Miriam|last2=Leis |first3=Matthijs|last3=Leendertse |first4=Yves|last4=Punie |first5=Govert|last5=Gijsbers |first6=Paul|last6=Kirschner |first7=Slavi|last7=Stoyanov |first8=Bert|last8=Hoogveld |url=http://ftp.jrc.es/EURdoc/JRC66836.pdf |publisher=[[Joint Research Centre]] |year=2011 }} Examples of lifewide learning implementations can be found in the [[Hong Kong]] primary and secondary school systems, {{cite web |url=http://www.edb.gov.hk/index.aspx?nodeID=3110&langno=1 |publisher=Hong Kong primary and secondary school system |title=Life-wide learning }} and the Surrey Centre for Excellence in Professional Training and Education (SCEPTrE) at the [[University of Surrey]] where the concept of lifewide learning and its recognition through a lifewide learning award was developed (Jackson 2011). The [http://lifewideeducation.uk/ Lifewide Education Community] has been established to promote and support lifewide learning, education and personal development. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=Barnett|first=R. |year=2011 |chapter=Lifewide education: a new and transformative concept for higher education. |editor-first=N. J.|editor-last=Jackson |title=Learning for a Complex World: A lifewide concept of learning, education and personal development |publisher=Authorhouse |isbn=978-1-4567-9370-8 }} * {{cite book |last=Desjardins|first=R. |year=2004 |title=Learning for Well Being. Studies in Comparative and International Education |location=Stockholm|publisher=Institute of International Education |isbn=978-91-7265-792-2 }} * {{cite book |last=Jackson|first=N.J. |year=2011 |chapter=The lifelong and lifewide dimensions of living, learning and developing |editor-first=N. J.|editor-last=Jackson |title=Learning for a Complex World: A lifewide concept of learning, education and personal development |publisher=Authorhouse |isbn=978-1-4567-9370-8 }} [[Category:Philosophy of education]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox monument |monument_name = Monument to Chocolate |native_name = Памятник шоколаду |image = |caption = |coordinates = {{coord|55|55|05|N|39|10|31|E|region:RU_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |location = [[Pokrov, Vladimir Oblast|Pokrov]], [[Vladimir Oblast]], [[Russia]] |designer = [[Ilya Shanin]] |type = |material = bronze |length = |width = {{convert|600|kg|abbr=on}} |height = {{convert|3|m|ft}} |begin = |complete = 2009 |open = 1 July 2009 |dedicated_to =[[chocolate]] |map_image = |map_text = |map_width = |relief = |extra = }} The '''Monument to Chocolate''', commonly known as '''Chocolate Fairy''' ({{lang-ru|Шоколадная фея}}), is a monument in the town of [[Pokrov, Vladimir Oblast|Pokrov]], [[Vladimir Oblast]], [[Russia]].
A [[bronze statue]] was created in 2009 and is known as the first monument to [[chocolate]] in the world.<ref name=ria>{{cite news|url=http://sputniknews.com/russia/20090701/155406133.html|title=Statue of chocolate fairy goes up in Russian town|agency=RIA Novosti|date=1 July 2009|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref> The monument is shaped as a chocolate bar, and represents a figure of a magic [[fairy]] holding a chocolate in her hands.<ref name=gen4trip>{{cite web|url=http://gen4trip.com/en/source-article/view?id=60833 |title=Monument chocolate|website=Gen4Trip|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref> The monument was unveiled on 1 July 2009, not far from the Pokrov [[Museum of Chocolate (Pokrov)|Museum of Chocolate]].<ref name=ria/>
The monument was given to the town by [[Kraft Foods]] to mark the 15th anniversary of the company’s operation in Russia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.erih.net/nc/de/regionale-routen/spanien/katalonien/detail.html?user_erihobjects_pi2%5BshowUid%5D=19074|title=Museum of Chocolate|publisher=European Route of Industrial Heritage|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Jamie|last=Rann|url=http://calvertjournal.com/articles/show/475/bizarre-russian-monuments|title=Statue of limitations: the monuments that taste forgot|website=The Calvert Journal|date=26 February 2013|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref> Kraft Foods' chocolate factory is well known as a producer of chocolate under the brands [[Alpen Gold]], [[Milka]], and [[Vozdushny]], is the backbone enterprise of Pokrov.
Twenty sculptors from the cities of [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]] and [[St. Petersburg]] participated in the competition for the best design of the monument.<ref name=russia-ic>{{cite web|url=http://www.russia-ic.com/news/show/8540/#.V4BsTdLhBdh|title=A monument to Chocolate unveiled in the town of Pokrov|agency=Russia-IC|date=3 July 2009|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref> The project to create the first monument to chocolate was awarded to [[Ilya Shanin]], a talented Vladimir sculptor and winner of the European sand sculptors' championship whose works were displayed in the cities of [[Germany]], [[Austria]] and [[Belgium]].<ref name=russia-ic/> It took him a year and a half to complete the sculpture.<ref name=ria/>
The monument is {{convert|3|m|ft}} tall and weighs {{convert|600|kg|abbr=on}}.
A legend associated with the statue says that if one makes a wish and rubs the chocolate tile in the Fairy's hand, his/her life will be sweeter.<ref name=gen4trip/>

{{redirect|Professional standards|the Metropolitan Police unit|Directorate of Professional Standards}} '''National Occupational Standards''' ('''NOS''') specify UK standards of performance that people are expected to achieve in their work, and the knowledge and skills they need to perform effectively.
NOS, which are approved by UK government regulators, are available for almost every role in every sector in the UK. For example, there are NOS for: * [http://www.people1st.co.uk/qualification-reform/national-occupational-standards-nos workers in hospitality, leisure, travel & tourism] * [https://www.skillsforcare.org.uk/Standards-legislation/National-Occupational-Standards/National-Occupational-Standards.aspx care workers] * [http://www.skillsactive.com/standards-quals/national-occupational-standards sports coaches] * [http://www.ccskills.org.uk/Qualifications/Standards/tabid/193/Default.aspx museum staff] * [http://www.skillsforjustice.com/template01.asp?pageid=37 probation officers] * [http://www.lantra.co.uk/research-standards/national-occupational-standards-0 those working in environmental conservation] * [https://www.instructus-skills.org/apprenticeship-qualifications/apprenticeships-qualifications-nos/ those working in business and administration].
All approved National Occupational Standards are available for downloading free of charge from the [http://www.ukstandards.org.uk/ NOS Directory].
==Components of NOS==
According to the SSDA<ref>SSDA, 2007b, pp2-3</ref> (the Sector Skills Development Agency, replaced in 2008 by the [[UK Commission for Employment and Skills]] and the Federation for Industry Sector Skills and Standards, comprising all 19 [[Sector Skills Councils]]), a unit of NOS must comprise: * '''Title''', reflecting the content of the NOS * '''Overview''', an introductory section providing a brief summary of the NOS to help the user judge whether it is relevant to them * '''Performance criteria''', defining in detail what is expected of the individual * '''Knowledge and understanding''', what the individual needs to know and/or understand to enable them to meet the performance criteria
NOS may also have sections covering: * '''Scope''', specifying the range of circumstances or situations that have a critical impact on the activity when carrying out the performance criteria * '''Elements'''. A NOS can be divided into two or more discrete elements which describe the activities the person has to carry out. * '''Values and behaviours''', the personal attributes an individual is expected to demonstrate within the NOS.
==Using NOS==
NOS can be used to support any and all human resource management and development activities, as shown in the [http://www.skillsforjustice.com/las/section_b/index.html toolkit] developed for Skills for Justice to support the use of the NOS for Legal Advice.
NOS are also used in the UK as the basis for [[National Vocational Qualification]]s and [[Scottish Vocational Qualification]]s.

The '''Lao National Tourism Administration''' ''(LNTA)'' is the [[government agency]] responsible for [[government|governing]], [[Promotion (marketing)|promoting]] and [[wikt:development|developing]] the [[tourism industry]] of [[Laos]]. The LNTA is a ministry-level agency, reporting directly to the [[prime minister]]'s office. <ref>[http://www.tourismlaos.gov.la/about-lnta.htm LNTA, 'About LNTA']</ref>
The [[Chairman]] of the LNTA is H.E. Mr.Somphong Mongkhonvilay. The agency is located in [[Vientiane]].<ref>[http://www.tourismlaos.gov.la/contact-us.htm LNTA, 'Contact us']</ref>
==See also== *[[Politics of Laos|Government of Laos]] *[[Tourism in Laos]]
==External links== Including the Agency page itself, there are four official links currently listed on the Agency's 'Contact us' page.<ref>[http://www.tourismlaos.gov.la/contact-us.htm LNTA, 'Contact us']</ref>
